movie_review_blurb: Only Yesterday remains a poignant classic in the 21st century.
Derek Cianfrance's film is a beautifully sustained study in adult themes of emotional crisis.
Stark Trek Beyond emphasizes the inter-personal dynamics of the USS Enterprise, and functions best as an extended team-building exercise.
Brady Corbet reaches for a dreary self-importance akin to Michael Haneke's The White Ribbon.
For the Dardennes, this is typical moral-message territory, which they approach too deliberately.
The simmering insinuations of Nicolas Winding Refn's film eventually flower into full-on exploitation.
Xavier Dolan adapts a talky play into something that could feasibly have the same emotional effect as a silent film.
movie_title: It's Only the End of the World (Juste la fin du monde) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Kleber Mendonça Filho's message in Aquarius is for a Brazil to recognize the strength and power of its heritage.
For Almodóvar, the film represents a holding pattern similar to the ones that his characters can't escape from.
For Assayas, the film represents a holding pattern similar to the one that Kristen Stewart's character can't escape from.
Maren Ade always possesses as fine an instinct for calibrating the emotions of her characters as any working director.
There's a quietly revelatory virtue to Jarmusch's film in its resistance to disturb its subject's life, to adhere to any typical conventions of film drama.
It finds little grooves of humanity to explore in its characters, and in its milieu, in between the expected plot beats.
At maybe half or a quarter of the length, American Honey might've gotten by on this surface-level vision.
The issue with X-Men: Apocalypse is that Bryan Singer suggests so many possible directions to go in and still chooses the least interesting one.
Jon Favreau draws heavily on his film's animated predecessor for plot, characterizations, songs, and set pieces, but doesn't know how to fit these familiar elements into his own coherent vision.
One gets the sense that power and meaning have been accumulated at a pace appropriately representative of Kirsten Johnson's own experiences.
It finds a benefit in its genre affiliation, evenly distributing its action in quick bursts of fluidly animated fight choreography.
Donnie Yen's performance is so good that it's a shame Wilson Yip's films have never strived to be more than briskly entertaining hagiography.
It exists less as a meaningful extension of its world than as a fan-service deployment device.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A Spike Lee joint in the urgent sociopolitical register of Radio Raheem's boombox--a call to arms that's also a call to disarm.
Throughout, director Justin Kurzel's stagey pretensions clash with each of his aesthetic choices.
What tends to right Moonlight, even when Barry Jenkins's filmmaking drifts into indulgence, is the strength of its actors.
It's pock-marked by the conservative dramatic conventions and overt political gestures that have marred much of Ken Loach's recent output.
Cruelty here can feel pretty cheap, perhaps a result of Bruno Dumont not knowing how to effectively command comedy yet.
The film's searching images counterpoint the hyper-articulate methodology of its characters' sense of imbalance and uncertainty.

For those hoping that there may have been a substantial uptick in quality between J.J. Abrams's The Force Awakens and Rian Johnson's The Last Jedi-in much the same way that The Empire Strikes Back improved on Star Wars-you may need a new hope.
It manifests a mounting sense of disillusionment, suggesting that the rodeo lifestyle many characters so unreservedly romanticize often leads to physical and psychological ruin.

Call Me by Your Name is a fairly straightforward coming-of-age story that's at its finest in moments when the relationships take on larger meanings than their literal context implies, and Luca Guadagnino finds evocative aesthetic expressions for them.
An empty exercise in imitative long-take aestheticism, A Ghost Story fills its distractingly round-cornered frame with endless repetitions on a visual gag.
It offers not only compelling social-realist ideas on its surface, but finds visually evocative ways to express them.
movie_title: BPM (Beats Per Minute) (120 battements par minute) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The film is at its strongest when it keys its intoxicating aesthetic to Robert Pattinson's performance.
The breezy Claire's Camera isn't only charming and funny, but also one of Hong's most formally intuitive and sharply written films in some time.
Michel Hazanavicius's co-opts Godard's personal life for cheap prestige-picture sentiment.
Yourself and Yours's commitment to its various extreme ambiguities is a crucial facet of the film's success.
Claire Denis's Let the Sunshine In is an exquisite romantic comedy whose laughs are sad and whose sadness is funny.
movie_title: Let the Sunshine In (Un beau soleil intérieur) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The meticulousness of Todd Haynes's execution overburdens his work's conceptually exhilarating sense of wonder.
Okja suggests that the sarcastic humor of Bong Joon-ho's best films doesn't translate well.
Dome Karukoski often excels at elevating his linear, historically conscious plotting with more abstract symbolism and ellipsis.
The film leaves the lasting impression of a story that takes place in its own elitist and hermetically sealed world.
Sleight never shows much interest in exploring how blackness can inform its genre's tropes.
It's neatly organized around not only the changing of the seasons, but a Disney-branded circle-of-life ethos.
Lady Macbeth eventually turns into a meaningless, mean-spirited, and proudly irredeemable non-character study.
Beach Rats is most compelling when it puts a self-aware focus on Harris Dickinson's sculpted male figure.
The film builds, out of an outlet for discussing the tragedy of one family, into an emotionally, intellectually, and aesthetically complex work of essay and memoir.
Rogue One is less the fetish object that The Force Awakens is because it at least has the ambitions to create its own character dynamics and plot routes rather than coast on existing ones.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Add The Red Turtle to the growing stack of largely disappointing films from Ghibli's new generation of untested directors.
The elusive and suddenly quite prolific Terrence Malick is fascinated, and beguiled, by nothing less than the legacy of all existence in his long-gestating, avant-nature doc.
Arnaud Desplechin's latest simultaneously collapses and expands his entire body of work, reflexively revealing its many layers, like a pop-up book.
Quote not available.
Excellent stuff -- it won't just be kids that love this film!
High-Rise is a competent adaptation, but it exhibits a lifelessness unsettlingly close to Ballard's worst dystopian pronouncement of late capitalism: its thorough boredom.
Inferno, and the Da Vinci Code universe, is cinema freed from the burdens of meaningfulness, of source code, of logical consequence.

The cinema, so infatuated with loud bangs and flowering orange blasts, does, as Ivo says, cheat us. Director/writer Zaza Urushadze instead gives us a clever, claustrophobic plot befitting a three-act play.
A jubilant and delightful trifle that - much like many of his other 44 films - ponders the rhyme and reason of our existence, however futile or fruitful that may be.
Lack of originality and insipid screenwriting may soon be read as the autopsy of this actively tiresome genre.
Antithetical to the horror excursions Sam Raimi built his name on, iOz the Great and Powerful is a heartwarming fantasy drenched in opulence.
Effectively illustrates the great heights we occasionally rise to for the ones we love.
An orgasmic spoof of every romantic comedy since time immemorial.
Jose Padilla's RoboCop is a galvanizing action picture that doesn't settle for merely retelling Verhoeven's original narrative, but updating it, both visually and thematically.
This is not a film about love, and all the joy, pain and heartbreak that comes along with it; but it sure does feel endless.

Batra's directorial debut is no monumental step forward in the medium, but it does belong to a rare breed of movies that embraces the prospect of new and unforeseen love wholeheartedly, without cynicism or superficiality.
My lasting wish is that Neeson, now 61, retires this grating schtick soon. His Golden Years are nigh, and his undeniable talents need not be wasted any longer.
Despite being filmed and set in Chicago, Divergent feels like a manufactured product churned out by the Hollywood system.
Dubious religious content aside, God's Not Dead is, above all, a dismal piece of filmmaking.
Underneath Bad Words' thick layer of sardonicism and snark, there is heart. You just have to dig deep. Very deep.
It takes all of 10 minutes for Doremus' film to reveal itself to us: this is a movie about a conflicted father who has arrived at a crossroads, both morally and artistically.
Like the rambling speech that opens Dom Hemingway, Richard Shepard's initially amusing, genre-less piece of filmmaking tragically expends its virtues thin by about the 30-minute mark.
A formalist masterwork: moody, meditative and mystifying.
I left with the unshakable feeling that this is the type of movie Costner would've starred in (and made better) 20-years ago.
Depending on how the next few decades unfold, people will look back at Transcendence as either a prophetic or surreal piece of filmmaking.
The film's modus operandi-set entirely in an automobile-hinders the script's ability to evolve into anything resonant.
Webb's second entry into this tiresome franchise amounts to little more than a case study in superhero movie banality.
From the opening frame to the closing credits it's clear that Words and Pictures is not too concerned with either of its eponymous art forms.
A tired exercise in scatology, a film laced with enough poop, piss and penis joke to last you a lifetime.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Rasoulof's dissident return to filmmaking is ultimately little more than a sporadically searing, unfocused and listless treatise on the pervasive censorship enforced by the autocratic Iranian government.

The film excels beyond a mere home-video replete with nostalgia and admiration, instead morphing into a living testament of De Niro Sr's profound work - an art galley so big and beautiful not even a Peggy Guggenheim exhibit could compete.
movie_title: Remembering The Artist Robert De Niro, Sr. (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Like the man himself, the film, with its immaculate black-and-white compositions and cluttered plotting, is riddled with virtues and vices, high and lows
Drones is in constant combat against itself, poorly balancing searing commentary on excessive drone use and rampant stupidity.
The emotions feel calculated, not earned.
Jaggedly oscillates between action absurdity and familial drama.
Deserving neither a love letter nor an autopsy, Paul Feig's fifth directorial feature is as aggressively average a movie as I've seen in recent memory.
That's My Boy serves as a morally bankrupt reminder that Sandler, much like many of us, has no interest in changing his ways.
It's difficult to carefully consider Alive Inside: A Story of Music & Memorywhen it feels like a sappy high school video project.
A disappointment from an ingenious and intelligent filmmaker
Gunn's listless adventure through space is not as uproarious as the Iron Man series, as thrilling as the Spider-Man franchise, or as dramatically serious as Nolan's Batman trilogy.
The film has a message worth grasping; sometimes it takes a departure from your comfort zone to truly understand what you have in life and what's important to you.
The type of metaphysical mediation on marriage, love, and death that insists, allows, and rewards introspection.
Charming as Lewin's script may be, the end result provides little more than underwhelming sentiments filled with indifference and frustration.
There's no grand epiphany or blinding revelation, just cogent storytelling framing a provocative and devastating incident in American history.
Few films in recent memory have effectively pulled at the heartstrings like this.
Malick has the unnatural talent to evolve a simplistic and adolescent game of hide and go seek into a profound and existential search into the character's hearts and minds.
Lack of originality and insipid screenwriting will soon read as the autopsy of this actively tiresome genre.
A creative blend of contemporary wit and love with Shakespearian vernacular.
We talk about the medium of film being a true art form of expression, The Master, in cinema's purest 70mm beauty and wonder, is the reason why.
Despite suffering from a lack of conviction, it clearly comes from personal place deep within Thornton thoughts.
However, the bigger issue at play here is the lack of subtlety, a concept seemingly not invented at the time Sofia Coppola wrote and directed this movie.
Erotic, moving, twisted, devastating, and disturbing, The Paperboy lays all its cards out onto the table, open for both stern criticism and sanctimonious praise.
Prince Avalanche is about as low-key and subtle as contemporary filmmaking has to offer. Unfortunately, Green's latest effort is also one of the more grating and sluggish films in recent memory.
Blue Jasmine captures a manic and delusional woman attempting to rebuild herself after a prodigal life she received, but never deserved.
By its end, "Good Night, and Good Luck" evolves into a prophetic vision of how television and film can be used to illuminate or insulate, educate or entertain.
That Awkward Moment is neither romantic, nor comedic. Just idiotic.

There's a good chance that by the conclusion of Martin Scorsese's intoxicating, raucous, and shamelessly depraved "The Wolf of Wall Street" you're going to want to cleanse yourself through prayer, charity, or whatever it is that you do to feel virtuous.
Alex Ross Perry's third feature film is his most narratively satisfying and intellectually demanding one, demonstrating a maturation in both style and substance.
The Better Angels eschews any sort of narrative linearity (and occasionally, coherency) without entirely alienating its audience.
Like the cyclical cycle of violence and poverty, "Imperial Dreams" mercilessly envelops you in its narrative and refuses to let you go until you've been moved.

Shelton continues to subvert our expectations by imbuing "Laggies" with a humanistic spirit.
Vogt's first feature film seamlessly oscillates from bruising drama to uproarious Norwegian comedy with tact.
Sutton's sophomoric sophomore effort is a pseudo-existentialist excursion through the life of a nomadic singer struggling with artistic stagnation.
At least in the end, we'll always have Shame.
Into the Storm isn't the unmitigated disaster it appears to be. It's much worse.
Even the real Monuments Men wouldn't preserve The Monuments Men, an immeasurably insufferable piece of a filmmaking that does a complete disservice to the unsung heroes its depicting.
A movie so listlessly written and constructed that it nearly redefines tedium.

A spectacle without the spectacle, an autumnal, amorphous blockbuster that just sits there, suspended in mid-air, as you soak in its ceaseless banality.
Equal parts horror masterclass and internal home-invasion thriller, Ouija is as chilling and nerve-racking as they come.
In the final 20 minutes, West seems to finally figure out what kind of a movie he wanted to make.
A deeply disturbing film that, at its best, serves as a meditation on the intersection between power, inequitable relationships, and retribution.
The presentation is dull, the plot is plodding, and the characters are sketches of people we've seen in better films.
Strident rhetoric is required for describing Brad Peyton's latest film, a maddening hodgepodge of ideas that range from undercooked to unoriginal.
These elements are all well and good, but if you're above the age of 12, it becomes considerably harder to reconcile the sporadic tone-deafness.

I don't subscribe to the notion that a piece of art shows its entire hand within its first ten minutes, but director Eran Creevy's third feature doesn't inspire a whole lot of confidence with its bland introduction.
Transitions into an at once sleazy and slick genre thriller, enigmatic without being alienating. There's suspense in the movie's central mystery, enough to sustain the characters Katz has created.

None of the virtues of the Diary series came along for the ride.

movie_review_blurb: This layered, detailed approach translates to all facets of Good Time. It's a movie born into existence through true collaboration. It's clear the Safdie brothers are beyond substantive storytellers; they're astute delegators.

This is a film of highs and lows; there is no middle ground, no moment of silence, reflection, or introspection. It's like watching a prospective candidate give a mannered and rehearsed 80-minute speech on the campaign trail.
By nature of its central subject, it's a piece of work that infuriates and excites. It's a deeply upsetting movie, and then, sporadically, a hopeful one.

Where the film falls short, at times, is in Pace and Coon's representation of grieving and renewal. Whether it's an issue in the dialogue or direction, the actors struggle to break outside the same emotional quadrant.
It's staunchly pro-life, in the truest sense of the term.
If the original Nut Job was about the emergence of a single hero, the sequel is about a collective banding together to combat the powers that be. This is the film's greatest strength.
movie_title: The Nut Job 2: Nutty by Nature (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's a movie about two people that ends up being about no one at all.

First and foremost a heart-wrenching account of three lives, lost and scared and searching for repair.
By the hour mark, it becomes abundantly clear why this film was made: Jackie Chan wanted it to happen. Everyone else is fairly disposable.
The messiness of the script or the lack of an aesthetic approach just don't seem to matter all that much. "Hearts Beats Loud" knows exactly what it is.
If you like your movies in which two males treat women poorly, mock homosexuality and repeatedly slap each other in the face, this film is for you.
Nothing in what appears during the movie's 107-minute running time seems to truly honor those whose lives were irreversibly altered during this national tragedy.
Disjointed and disinterested in entertaining any and all prospective viewers, the overlong slab of melodrama is one of the most vanilla experiences at the movies in quite some time.
One of those rare movies that looks like it was fun to make, and is even more fun to watch.
Jenkins and McCraney have artfully cobbled together something that is impressionistic and wondrous, like a compendium of half-remembered memories, tinged by sadness.

A masterpiece.
A hypnotic confluence of action, comedy and hysteria that is at once unnerving, exhilarating and unlike anything I've ever seen.

Arguably the most vital film to come out of Hollywood in 2014.

A breathtaking cinematic essay.

A satirical confection in the same vein as "Cabin in the Woods."

Does a sub-par job probing the psyches of both Buddhafield's leader and its members.

A textbook example of ambition undercut by tonal and pacing inconsistency.

movie_review_blurb: Lang manages to make Blue Gardenia his own, and he does so not by transcending the banality of the material but by giving this banality a thematic (dare I say, philosophical) significance.
An enjoyable and gently involving portrayal of a fascinating talent. It isn't the most sophisticated biopic around but that's quite fitting for a subject who took such pride in his own naivety.

movie_review_blurb: A work of beauty as well as horror, Iraq In Fragments is one of the best of the many documentaries to come out of that ruined country. It's powerful, enlightening and necessarily depressing.
A higher 'dude' count than an Ashton Kutcher film.
It isn't original and it isn't subtle, but this is an intelligent and well-made war film that hammers its point home with explosive force.

For many directors this would be counted as a considerable success, but from the director of The Consequences Of Love, it seems like a disappointment. It's smart, it looks great and there are fantastic characters, but the motive power just isn't there.

movie_review_blurb: It's just dull.
movie_title: The Story of Marie and Julien (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Powerful and haunting sci-fi parable imbued by Tarkovsky with a multi-layered visual resonance and, despite its stately pace, raw emotional impact.
The filmmakers' methods are questionable, but the power of the resulting documentary and the importance of the issues it raises are not.
This is a real horror film -- it's painful to watch and there's no escape through thinking it's only a movie -- and it's correspondingly impressive.
A strange and bittersweet triumph.
Proof that there's far more to Tinto Brass than his ability to persuade pretty girls to show their bottoms.
The work of a unique, uncompromising talent at the height of his creative powers. Mouchette is difficult and depressing, but very powerful.
The action is tense. Dark shadows and long moody silences predominate. The dialogue is clipped and sparse: Melville's heroes are men and women of few words and big deeds.
A pioneering horror classic, and still one of the most successful anthologies to date.
This unique and meticulous work of art makes a fitting swansong for a cinematic genius.
Deserves to be enjoyed by a wider audience than it's had in recent years. Black Orpheus is all surface and glorious for it.
A clever film that may be provocatively political and deadly earnest but still has an infectious sense of fun and creative joy.
A compelling and disturbing testament to the enduring power of evil and the complexity of human nature.

movie_review_blurb: While it lacks the lightness of touch and smooth flow that distinguishes Bergman at his finest, this is still a powerful, profound work of art.
Some of the politics may not have aged well but its rich colours and passions burn as bright as the day it was made.
Vital and disquieting, this is a powerful depiction of the pity of war. As shocking today as it was on the day of its release.
movie_title: The Battle of Algiers (La Battaglia di Algeri) (1967)

movie_review_blurb: This anthology is a mixed bag.
Sharp jokes and heady nostalgia ensure it will at least please a wide audience.
A smart, amusing take on some serious issues that's fortunate in its excellent young leading lady and its ability to laugh at its own political excesses.

A touching story, relatively well told with the bonus of a fine backing track and eloquent interview subjects.
movie_title: Am I Black Enough for You? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A film that is unashamedly sentimental and all the better for it. It's not at all sickly and even quite acerbic at times, but it is sweet.
Deeply moving.
A worthy film, highlighting what seems to be a rank injustice, but one that is irritating and poorly put together.
Moments of high comedy and deep tragedy make this more than the average rehearsal and concert film.

A triumph of serious Hollywood filmmaking.
A worthy entry on Jean Simmons' impressive CV - and hopefully not the last. Shadows In The Sun might not be Spartacus but it does have a charm of its own.
A well made portrait of an intriguing man, presented with a tragic but resounding weight.

movie_review_blurb: Occasionally too reverent, this remains an effective evocation of a vibrant and interesting art scene, not to mention a touching paean to lost youth.
Michael Moore's best film to date. Entertaining, moving, funny, hard-hitting, right-on. It won't silence his critics, but it will give them something to think about.
Directors who come up with films with "sleep" in the title shouldn't be this dull if they don't want glib comments made about them. Yes, I Don't Want To Sleep Alone is a snooze-fest.
movie_title: I Don't Want to Sleep Alone (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Flawed editing and intrusive and irritating commentary hardly detract from the shock value of this disturbing documentary. Compulsory viewing for anyone in the least bit concerned about religious extremism.

A rewarding and cleverly constructed experiment - but not one that is easy to enjoy or warm to. All will agree that it's a fine thing that Rivette should still be pushing the boundaries, few will actually want to watch him doing it.

movie_review_blurb: A few serious points against Moore's credibility are overshadowed by a lot of dull posturing, unconvincing argument and unpleasant interviews. It's nothing like as good as the films made by the man it maligns.
Stylish, but never quite substantial enough, Half Moon never lives up to its stunning opening sequence.
A real treat. Captivating from its famous opening lines to its pyrotechnic finale, this is one of Hitchcock's finest -- and that's saying something.
Clumsy filmmaking and political analysis do not detract from the horror of the events the film bears witness too, nor the importance of its message.
Another no-frills success from one of Iran's most accessible directors.

A blistering, disturbing portrayal of one British soldier's attempt to get back to his Belfast barracks after being stranded behind enemy lines during the Troubles.
Retains a dreamlike quality that at times leaves the film in debt as much to Terrence Malick as Alejandro González Iñárritu.
movie_title: Dreams of Flight: The Golden Age...& Beyond (1984)

movie_review_blurb: The film's emotional complexity lends it a weight that has sustained its influence over the decades.

This film carries a similar weightiness and moral heft to those tomes to mortality and realpolitik, yet retains a dreamlike quality that at times leaves the film in debt as much to Terrence Malick as Alejandro González Iñárritu.
movie_title: The Golden Dream (La Jaula De Oro) (2015)

A refreshing change of pace for Ferrell and a delightfully dark change of mood in the doldrums of the summer blockbuster.
A movie that treads a well-worn path through a saturated field yet somehow feels like the freshest film of the year.
Ferrell makes this a movie worth your money, and you'll leave the theater laughing.

movie_review_blurb: By the end of the film, you may get the sense that these are good actors still in search of good, fully formed characters.
