movie_review_blurb: The Village doesn't quite return Shyamalan to the heights of The Sixth Sense. But it's close enough for discomfort.
For the most part, it shows exactly what it shows, so that when even the simplest cinematic mediation insinuates itself, it feels a bit like poetry - or conceptual magic.
In Another Country sets its characters adrift inside its own narrative sphere, letting them live several lives in the course of an hour and a half, and letting us share in their freedom.
Even as Ian's journey detours into National Lampoon-like farce, the movie remains faithful to a portrait of teens as they see themselves.

Given to misogynistic outbursts that border on the psychotic, Maxwell Bright (Patrick Warburton) is as unlikable as movie heroes come, yet director David Beaird insists there is Zen within this modern Neanderthal.

Suffering from what could be called Garden State syndrome, Sex and Breakfast demands that we empathize with the anguish of straight, white, financially privileged young people and their significantly hot significant others.
By eschewing any attempt at storytelling or character development, a film with all of the Western's fecund imagery and putrid fumes still ends up feeling as flat and distant as a gallery wall.
The best zombie movies shock us into a realization about ourselves and the world in which we live, but how much can zombies teach us when their world so closely resembles 1995?
Deception offers a fantasy even big money can't buy -- Wall Street as a cross between a James Bond adventure and a Victoria's Secret spread.
Epstein's film is conveniently short on interviews with the millions of mothers who have had positive experiences delivering in hospitals.
Byer's sincerity is the grounding force in a film that serves as a wrenching reminder that the answers to our most essential questions must come from within.

Laroque has starred in dozens of these featherweight comedies in France, but this material forces her to new grades of mildness. Even during shouting matches with Modine, her emotional pitch rarely exceeds a middling 25 MPH.
The film's final minutes erupt in a display of politicized melodrama so hysterical that it could almost be taken for camp if it wasn't so noxious.

Director Geoffrey Pepos wants to show that posttraumatic stress causes combat veterans to destroy themselves and the people they love, but he has little interest in unpacking his characters' war experiences beyond cliches.
Mentor might have rung truer had it allowed Pollard to stay a monster, rather than redeeming him in a predictably heartwarming climax.

More farce might have served the film well; as Parise draws from a playbook of medical melodrama and romantic-comedies clichés, her moral about living outside the box becomes harder and harder to swallow.
movie_title: Jack and Jill vs. the World (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Full of good intentions and scattered with more than a few gob-smacking scenes, this could have really taken it to Hollywood if only it had a little more to say than "war is hell here too."
The depth of talent in the cast and gag writing shines through, but it's only just enough to take your mind off of the flat animation.
A little dated bit Nic Roeg is always good value and David Bowie is perfetly cast.
movie_title: The Man Who Fell to Earth (1976)

movie_review_blurb: A rare and valuable movie, providing fascinating insight into another culture without pandering or being stuffy. Seek it out -- swim if you have to.
A great idea is weighed down by an over-egged screenplay, but the setting and cast bring out its best.

If more effort had been taken to smooth over TMNT's rough edges, this could have been a great movie. As it stands, there's just enough to keep littluns and hardcore fans of the 'phibian foursome amused.

You can rely on Goldthwaite to demolish sentimental notions with the power of a force ten gale, but clumsy filmmaking seriously hampers his idea's own effectiveness, resulting in a rather plodding black comedy.

A script that suffers the same problem as its characters - lack of confidence - is in dire need of a fire being lit under its arse. All involved could do with learning a thing or two from some scoundrels of the 'dirty, rotten' school.
Another lame attempt to bring extreme eroticis to the big screeen.
A story that deserves to be heard, but like the EV1, it's a quiet achievement that should have been much louder.
Got any kids who've been naughty this year? Here's their present.
The kids help get the film past its messy, low-budget look, aided by a strong ensemble of familiar adult faces.
Hit and miss tribute to the great melancholist.
Another 'nice' Sandler comedy that works, thanks to some smart and genuinely moving ideas at its core.
Aiming for an admirably lofty target, it's a case of close but no cigar. It's a long way from bad, but the wildly uneven tone sees it fall equally far from greatness.

The target audience - pre-teen girls - aren't going to notice the many shortfalls behind the camera. What they'll enjoy, regardless of quality, is some naughtiness true to the spirit of the series, Russell Brand and Girls Aloud.
The story, like the cinematography, is overly foggy and under-illuminated.
There's no way this story could ever have made a bad film, but a script that refuses sentimentality and fine acting elevate it just short of greatness.
It's certainly a Spike Lee film, but no Spike Lee Joint. Still, he's delivered a pacy, vigorous and frequently masterful take on a well-worn genre.

What begins as a series of pleasant revelations and a deft example of genre defiance is nearly crippled by cliche in its second half, but The Rock's surprising dramatic magnetism will hold you until the final whistle.
Von Trier's deconstructionist streak stymies this admirable attempt at a comedy.
movie_title: The Boss of it All (Direktøren for det hele) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A charmless, witless, lumbering mess. Almost nothing could redeem this lame comedy.
A late entry in a crowded field, Spiderwick works hard to set itself apart from the competition, and almost entirely succeeds - no mean feat these days.
There's too much story (a later, Georgia-set act falters), but this mostly rides comfortably on Khan's superb performance, and his chemistry with leading lady Kajol.
A decent, affectionate, fitfully funny take on the fantasy genre, but this could have been so much more. For fans of this sort of comedy only.
Despite one or two nice moments and the naturalistic tone, it's all a bit of a slog.
A captivating, and sometimes alarming, exposé of the business end of nuclear power. Watch as part of a behind-the-sofa double bill with Countdown To Zero.
Sub-standard battle scenes and ropey characterisation drain this powerful story of its impact. Less history than histrionic.
Ramirez's outstanding performance and Assayes' superb skill in storytelling make this a mini-series not to be missed.
An uneven stew of character development, violence and sub-Top Gear car chases. Disappointing.

Robinson and Duke are terrific, and while it's fantastic to see Cusack back doing all-out comedy, truly outstanding is Daily Show veteran Rob Corddry, who has to make horrible jerk Lou likable and funny.
Compelling and, for anyone who values truth, essential.
movie_title: Burma VJ: Reporter i et Lukket Land (Burma VJ: Reporting from a Closed Country) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Not for everyone, but fans of Dario Argento will find plenty to like about this otherworldly study of sex and sensuality.

More carefully measured than many of its American contemporaries, Traitor doesn't match the heights of Syriana, but sits comfortably above, say, The Kingdom for mapping out the complexities of its issues .
Anvil! is exactly what's needed to slap the recent rash of doomsayer documentaries in the face - preferably with a studded, fingerless leather glove.

Okay, it doesn't have an original bone in its body, but forgetting the awful title, Sex Drive has its share of snappy lines and decent gags. It's also got Seth Green and James Marsden on cracking form, which should never be underestimated.
Don't expect anything too profound from this middleweight fare - but it'll still be better than the inevitable remake.
While the characters sometimes feel roughly drawn, the casting is spot on.
There are plenty of good qualities in Charlie; it just needed to apply itself a little more.
Funny, vivacious and profound without being earnest, this is an utter delight.
movie_title: I Served the King of England (2008)

movie_review_blurb: An array of small successes can't support the crushing weight of the malformed screenplay. Not a complete loss by any means, though, and Walsh is a talent to keep an eye on.
Over-filled and self-indulgent, this is an irritating little film.
Semi-Pro isn't painful, but it's a very minor credit for everyone involved.
This is one of [Bay's] better films - mostly because the story is grounded in reality.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Great comedy catches people off guard. It pulls the rug out from under their feet and leaves them gasping for air. Dirty Grandpa does neither.

Jane Got a Gun is a serviceable, by-the-numbers western. I'm glad it survived the many obstacles of its production, but I'm not sure why the cast and crew fought so hard to save this rather safe, conventional movie.

Hail, Caesar! seems like a lark -- an inessential Coen Brothers film. It's not one of their best, but beneath the surface of this Old Hollywood satire lies a comforting statement from the siblings about their plans for the future.
Where to Invade Next is enlightening and engaging, but it lacks the thrillingly "cinematic" moments of Moore's other films.
This is the kind of film that will send shivers of excitement up your spine and tears of joy down your face.
You want a warts-and-all portrait? You want a painful yet uplifting and unforgettable drama? Look no further. This is one of the best films of the year.
Watching My Big Fat Greek Wedding 2 was much like visiting relatives. It was irritating and uncomfortable at first, but after a few drinks, I had a jolly good time.
It feels like an action thriller straight out of the '90s. And for the most part, its stars of yesteryear deliver the goods.
The film is ultimately about more than a kitty. It's about the lengths people are willing to go for friends. It's the best kind of comedy -- humor with heart.
Lively anchors the film with her tough yet tender performance, which is easily her best work to date.
The Forest is littered with breadcrumbs leading to a better film. Let's hope some other horror filmmakers find them.
Batman v Superman is a hot, steaming heap of trash.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Like [Tarantino's] early films, it thrills us simply with tough talk in tight spaces.

The film revolves around the famous feud between political pundits Gore Vidal and William F. Buckley Jr. It feeds our urge to be flies on the wall in the midst of such a fight. And it sheds light on why we all share that dark desire.
Mad Max: Fury Road makes you feel the heat of its apocalyptic atmosphere, the rust of the wreckage scraping beneath your fingers and the impossible hope that its characters will rise from the ashes.
Creed is a rare kind of franchise film. It pays homage to the first movie in the series but ultimately manages to step out of its shadow and stand on its own.

It's a fun time at the movies, but it doesn't give viewers the same shiver of excitement that Casino Royale and Skyfall evoked -- the shiver of seeing human drama play out in the middle of popcorn spectacles.
This film will linger in your heart long after the lights go up in the theater. It's the best movie of the year.
Steve Jobs is one of the best films of the year. Like the man himself, it's sharp, imaginative and unforgettable.
Crimson Peak is a lavish, refreshingly old-fashioned production.
Goosebumps isn't a completely bad film. It has some good laughs and surprisingly poignant moments of adolescent drama. But it's not nearly as memorable as its source material.

As he did with Prisoners, Villeneuve proves to be a master of mood. Unfortunately, the darkly atmospheric energy of Sicario is wasted on a story with very little substance. Like a drug, it's cool and alluring at first, but it ultimately leaves you empty.
The Infiltrator is worth seeing for Cranston alone.
Unlike most biopics, which rely on our nostalgia for another time, Straight Outta Compton reels us in with its raw reflection of our current reality.
The Stanford Prison Experiment is all too timely. This film puts its finger firmly on the pulse of America at the moment. It's harrowing and hard to watch, but you won't want to miss it.
While most summer spectacles aim to further immortalize popular heroes, this film reflects on one's mortality. It's a powerful look at a larger-than-life figure shrunken by sickness.
Walter isn't quite like anything you've seen before. Shot partly in Indianapolis on a shoestring budget, this quirky comedy is one of the best films out right now.
Krampus recalls the magic of Poltergeist, making monsters out of mundane objects, embedding the otherworldly in the everyday.

In this age of sequels, reboots and cinematic universes, maybe all that matters is keeping franchises alive, even if some entries are forgettable. But a lot of recent films seem to keep a series going for more compelling reasons than Jason Bourne.
Terrence Malick is pushing it.
It's definitely a tender and insightful comedy, but it's also as crude as they come.
Even after years in development hell, Suicide Squad feels half-hearted and unfinished -- like a comic book sketch that hasn't been inked or colored.
It's Hull's best work yet - an audacious ensemble comedy that feels like the best film the Farrelly Brothers never made.
70 Acres in Chicago chronicles an urban redevelopment disaster and the community that stood strong amid the destruction.
Nothing seems staged or manipulative here. All of these moments emerge organically and feel achingly real, reminding us of the magic in documentary filmmaking.
It's safe to say you haven't seen anything quite like Plank Face. This film is a shining example of the movie magic at work right here in Indy.
Scorsese grew up as a Catholic, and his intimacy with the subject matter here shines through every frame.
Patriots Day is a poignant portrait of heroism in the face of horror.
A mesmerizing exploration of the magical place we all call home.
movie_title: Voyage of Time: The IMAX Experience (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The Conjuring 2 won't send the same shiver of movie magic up your spine, but it's a solid sequel with plenty of tricks up its sleeve.
Bleed for This is the kind of film we all need right now.
Inferno is a dumb popcorn movie disguised as a smart mystery. It's packed with historical insights and religious iconography, but it ultimately leaves you feeling empty.
If only this film focused more on stirring up empathy from viewers, connecting viewers hearts to the characters' pasts more than dazzling our eyes.
Money Monster doesn't fully come alive on screen. It tries too hard to make a statement, losing sight of the people amid the politics.
Amid countless remakes like Vacation and sequels like Neighbors 2, which doggedly push for crude atmospheres, this film creates a world that's pure and naturally absurd.
Harrowing yet exhilaratingly imaginative, A Monster Calls is a brilliant fable that sheds a warm, hopeful light on one of life's darkest chapters.
Popstar puts its finger firmly on the computerized pulse of contemporary pop music. This is a cathartic satire -- a much-needed roast of the celebrities currently driving the world mad.
Florence Foster Jenkins is one of the better films of the year.
Author: The JT LeRoy Story is a testament to the magic of art and how it can make a fantasy feel achingly real.
If you look past the surface, dig deeper and trust its mysterious, supernatural mission, it could make for one of the most emotional experiences you'll have at the movies this year.
This isn't Eastwood's best film, and it doesn't completely succeed in translating the true story to the big screen. But it's not without moments of spine-tingling movie magic.
Unfortunately, this one loses its power as soon as you leave the theater, and it poses no threat of haunting your dreams.
Although it's based on a story that took place in the late '90s/early 2000s, this film holds a hypnotic mirror up to today's America.
Demon isn't a bad film; it's a disappointing one.
If you're a fan of the first film, you'll bask in the warm familiarity of this one.

Moonlight is a film full of mesmerizing mystery. As it slowly searches through a young man's conflicted heart, it creates a moment-to-moment feeling of discovery. It leaves you with a sense of pure wonder.
The film is funny in a light, wispy sort of way that never cuts as deep as it should.
Maybe it's not an obvious sequel, but this film certainly has the same spirit as Cloverfield, keeping viewers guessing until the last shot.
Like the best sports dramas, this one is a crowd-pleaser. As clichéd as this sounds, it's true; this is the kind of film that will make you want to stand up and cheer.
Miss Sloane holds a mirror up to the ugliness of the political world. It's a hypnotic, haunting spectacle.
Child of God is brazenly, outstandingly bad, as vague, pretentious, and pointless as its sorry title.
The Man on Her Mind has a terminal case of the cutes.
Coldwater is almost boastfully grim.
Torture and S&M fetishists will savor its every knife-plunging, blood-splattering, leather-crinkling moment. Everyone else should stay far, far away.
movie_title: The Strange Color of Your Body's Tears (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Archaeology of a Woman is a decidedly well-made, unnerving film.
Under the Electric Sky manages to be amusing even while it's annoying you.
Bessis has a natural screen radiance, and Defa is disarming, even at his most selfish. But the script's naïveté is galling.
While not as kinky, dark, or schizoid as debuting director/screenwriter Michael Medeiros intends, Tiger Lily Road succeeds on its own small, claustrophobic level.
Stewing and scenic, unfolding amid the islands and catacombs of Crete and Athens, and loaded with the usual film-noir delights: fedoras, lipstick-stained highballs, and bare-knuckled fistfights.
[It] never achieves its intended weightiness.
In the end, Relationship Status is wan when it tries to be scandalous.
It's puzzling why a talent like Macy bothered with a project that is so long on sentiment and short on comic relief - and unclear on what it wants to say on a variety of hot-button topics.
It's an unsolved mystery in Hollywood why so many based-on-true-life polemical films end up so unremarkable.
Only those who still quiver at the shopworn lament that advancing technology is destroying the world will find the philosophizing vital in this bookish stupor.
This film is numbingly dull, an outlaw-on-the-run saga as laconic and slow-moving as its fierce, hirsute protagonist.
Characters who might have been portrayed as Bible Belt nut-jobs come off as unconditionally loving.
Viewers must work as hard as Lee to determine past from present; you may feel amnesiac yourself by film's end.

Aftermath is not merely a grandiose apology for Holocaust-era complicity. It taps a richer vein with its examination of why such an apology is ultimately so empty, even if it takes profound bravery to apologize.
Even at its well-meaning best, Refuge is listless.
A funny, woozy, infectiously cheery look at a still-persevering (though struggling) national treasure.
Zicherman should have trusted his dark instincts; he did too much micromanaging of his own.
Content-wise ... it's little more than a gooey, life-affirming parable about keeping the faith.
movie_title: I Will Follow You Into The Dark (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The Counselor is the cumbersome end product of a high-minded writer trying to slum and a slick director aiming for cosmic depth.
Slumbers excels because it trusts the audience to imagine its own version of Phnom Penh's golden age.
Those with a fetish for the smashing of faces - against rocks, bourbon glasses, windshields, and the like - might enjoy Edgar Marie's crime thriller Paris Countdown.
The film registers like a more compelling episode of A&E's The First 48, complete with overwrought, ominous music and tacky re-enactments.
Dorado proves nimble at chase scenes, and the ending is immensely satisfying: not impossible to predict, per se, but probably the third or fourth possible outcome you imagined.
As a whole, Cold Turkey is too busy and offers no fresh insight on the inner hysteria of seemingly upright WASPs. The actors work hard, but their roles are mostly one-note.
[Director] Pantera knows just when to cut back on the loopy, jumpy camerawork and let a scene breathe.
As pleasant and unaffected as its very modest subject ...
movie_title: In No Great Hurry: 13 Lessons in Life with Saul Leiter (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Girl on a Bicycle is like Micki + Maude minus the outrage, complexity, or crack timing.
It's hard to see why IFC Films would attach themselves to this ho-hum scarefest.
This needlessly incoherent thriller treats its convoluted nonsense with grave seriousness.
The stickups, while plenty funny - an Uzi firing uncontrollably can still be hilarious - lack any sense of dread or danger.
A dense, often chilling work that manages, in 95 minutes, to devote equal screen time to an overwhelming number of Egyptian Jews ...
Its content is culled from so many different movies that it seems the end product of a particularly unfocused pitch meeting.
Theo Love's mesmerizing documentary Little Hope Was Arson is as evenhanded as it is unsettling.
[A] bleakly funny debut.
The tension never lets up.
This is a maudlin, manipulative film, and while it's never aggressively annoying, that's only because it severely lacks energy.
Ennui and eroticism make an oddly alluring combo in Michelangelo Antonioni's La Notte.
It's extremely likable, but sentimental is the last thing a tale about growing up poor and angry in working-class, late-1970s England should strive to be.
The film, in the end, is a celebration of a humble artist who easily could have been - and perhaps deserves to be - a megalomaniac.
movie_title: Sky Ladder: The Art of Cai Guo-Qiang (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A gruesomely riveting sucker punch of a movie.
movie_title: Henry: Portrait Of A Serial Killer - 30th Anniversary (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Shares the flaws of Lumet's own movies: It's workmanlike and impassioned, but ultimately preaching to the choir.
Byrne never resorts to such cheap tricks as matching the imagery to what the interviewees are saying, and the film is no hagiography.
The film is not without its trenchant moments, most rooted not in peace but in science.
The film ... transcends its familiar "career vs. home obligations" conflict.
Whether the real-life Martinez is this hotheaded and quick-tempered is left a mystery, but it matters not a whit, because even five minutes in the company of this Martinez is excruciating.
While the film, to its credit, doesn't become a trite morality play, the ending is thin and contrived nonetheless.
Whenever Plummer is onscreen, The Exception is scintillating entertainment. Unfortunately, it gets bogged down ...
Frank Serpico, though sprawling and seething, isn't a hagiography. It probes instead into Serpico's personal agonies.
[A] bone-chilling, hallucinatory tour de force ...
Red Knot exhibits such spot-on, heartbreaking honesty about behaviors that tear many couples apart ... that it's easy to forgive Cohen his metaphorical excesses.
There are no haters here, no bullies, and the only real enemy is the self-repression that plagues the shy, closeted Korean Angeleno teenager at its center.
We don't just learn about Deleuze; we learn it is possible to love blues music, Maria Montez, Communist propaganda films, and Cheech and Chong in equal measure.
movie_title: The Thoughts That Once We Had (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Flames, though energetically crafted, erotic, and at times heartfelt, is an exasperatingly esoteric meditation on love.
Viewers are graced with a few disappointingly subdued action scenes, two humdrum romantic subplots, and a virtual museum of bad acting.
Unlocking the Cage is a genuine rarity: a rather happy documentary about a losing battle for justice.
[A] dour, dreary drama ...
It ultimately succumbs to the bland, sentimental uplift we've come to expect from such outings.
Most of this frantic moviemaking is more disorienting than riveting.
Terrific documentaries are a dime a dozen; ones this multifaceted are to be cherished.

The movie is saccharine. The tone is set from the get-go by that lazy, obsequious title - it sounds like some bogus self-help seminar that one of Farley's characters would have smashed to smithereens.
It might make you long for a return to movies in which teens have a greater vocabulary than their parents.
Fitfully captivating, though plenty amusing.
movie_title: How to Smell a Rose: A Visit with Ricky Leacock at his Farm in Normandy (2015)

movie_review_blurb: In a very frenetic two hours, Kim demonstrates every conceivable way in which one grown man can injure another.
Merhar saves In the Shadow of Women with the simplest of gestures: a smile.

While Spender spends enough time with both new and retired jockey legends to collect a gold mine of macho, bullheaded rapport, you wish she delved deeper into the more sinister, behind-the-scenes wheelings and dealings.
We've seen many an insider doc about films destroyed by their creators' chutzpah (Overnight, Lost in La Mancha), but what's most wrenching here is McQueen's displays of vulnerability and tenderness.
movie_title: Steve McQueen: The Man & Le Mans (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Bialis's growing immersion in the town is poignant, even admirable.
Vivid and enlightening ...
movie_title: Ingrid Bergman in Her Own Words (Jag är Ingrid) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Heartrending throughout, Iraqi Odyssey is everything you want in a documentary - informative, involving, and eager to decipher complex, often paradoxical historical conundrums.
Before, one left the theater befuddled; one now leaves the theater equally befuddled but also moved, even genuinely disturbed.
movie_title: Until the End of the World (Bis ans Ende der Welt) (1992)

movie_review_blurb: Stiff, humorless, tension-free ...
Dominique Abel and Fiona Gordon prove worthy heirs to the gangly genius of Jacques Tati in this surreal comic gem.
Shaky recordings, interspersed with reconstruction scenes at the VJ HQ, look surprisingly sharp and give Burma VJ an unforgettable and powerful immediacy.
movie_title: Burma VJ: Reporter i et Lukket Land (Burma VJ: Reporting from a Closed Country) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's unusually tender and eccentric, and Koppel's personal sadness at the passing of this way of life is palpable.
Leaving behind the aromatic fantasy of Perfume, Tom Tykwer weighs in with a tense and exhilarating entry into the spy genre. This is an espionage thriller well worth investing in.

We've seen this kind of picturesque rural drama before, but director Reha Erdem still hews a rich poetry from the material. The story's elegantly structured around the five daily calls-to-prayer given from a parapet with stunning views.
Shot in shades of bleached-out khaki brown and augmented by a heart-rending orchestral score, it's a unique and intensely moving elegy for wasted lives.
Jimmy Carter may not be the most memorable ex-White House resident, but his post-presidency record as a battler for humanitarian causes takes some beating.
Even John Rhys-Davies as the PM struggles to lend gravitas to the comically earnest dialogue and knee-jerk conspiracy theorising.
movie_title: 31 North 62 East (Too Close to the Truth) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Lumbering and beautiful, Zvyagintsev leaves few doubts that we're in the hands of a fledgling master: there's lots of striking visuals to keep you from itching for the exit as the leisurely running time unspools.
Yet his unerring eye for the absurdity of human behaviour and the rituals we invent for ourselves makes this a blackly humorous treat.
The film has a cheeky comic streak that offsets all the streetwise grandstanding.
Drawing affecting performances from a fledgling cast, Defurne's film is a poignant snapshot of square-peg adolescent desire, vibrantly set against a colourful backdrop.
Interviews with Spitzer, those exclusive madams and vengeful Republicans are woven into a compulsively fascinating probe of power and its dark side.
movie_title: Client 9: The Rise and Fall of Eliot Spitzer (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Nearly 90 years on, Eisenstein's masterpiece is still guaranteed to get the pulse racing.
Exciting but one-sided, Bouchareb's film is a Melville-lite study of honour among dangerous men.
The goats are the stars in Michelangelo Frammartino's dialogue-free portrait of a remote Calabrian farming community.
More interested in street cred than plot cred: never has a bunch of kids looked less likely to want to end it all.

As Jonathan Pryce reads passages and academic voices take turns to chew over Sebald's visionary opus, B&W footage of country roadsides and wind-blasted coastlines turns rural Suffolk into something truly otherworldly.
Nasheed may be a small fish in a big geopolitical pond, but his enterprise and optimism are a welcome complement to eco doc doom and gloom.
Breaking the cycle of abuse, Buck's deep-rooted respect for these dignified animals is truly inspiring.
If you've got the stomach for it this is an intoxicating vision of life at the end of its tether.
Jaw-dropping in colour and splendour, but if the constant awe gets a bit tiring, at its best you can genuinely feel some great wheel turning.
Take a pro basketball player with a career-threatening knee injury and an ugly-duckling nurse and you've got the blueprint for a steamroller of sopp that knows no shame.
Don't Worry Baby is more than just a father-son comedy, it's an emotional roller coaster, too.
Mark Gatiss's drama, An Adventure in Space and Time, is a lovely way to kick off the (50th Anniversary) celebrations.
movie_title: An Adventure in Space and Time (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The late, brilliant Tim Pigott-Smith is mesmerising as Charles. It's not an impression, thankfully, nor was the actor made up to look like him (that would have been tiresome), but an interpretation of character.
They've changed it, not just unnecessarily but unquestionably for the worse, and that's a travesty.
So preposterous perhaps, but also honest and brilliant - the film, and the man.
The TV drama is a simpler thing then, of course it is. But it's still a deeply affecting portrait of loss and what that does to love. It is painful, but not entirely without hope, given time.
Not a neuroscientist herself, then, nor a science journalist, but an expert in another way, in that Lotje Sodderland has experienced coming round in a strange world she didn't recognise.
Big Hero 6 accomplishes its goal of entertaining those young enough not to notice how dispiritingly familiar it is as both an animated and superhero movie.
The Giver lets you watch a novel bit of social sci-fi turn into another Hunger Games pretender before your very eyes.
Featuring a star and brand of spy action that are both well past their prime, The November Man makes for a dull, regressive espionage thriller.
Ambition trumps answers in The One I Love, thanks to a killer hook that consumes the film, for better and worse.
The unique hooks of When the Game Stands Tall do as much to muddle its message as distinguish it from the usual cliches of high school sports dramas.
Maps to the Stars sees Cronenberg relapsing into old habits, for better or worse.
Coming Home is an affecting pocket magnum of a melodrama: it looks small and hits big.
The Last 5 Years has some catchy tunes, a clever structure, and Anna Kendrick. When it comes to breezy romantic musicals, it's hard to ask for much more.
Detective thrillers rarely get as baffling and repugnant as The Captive.
An unassuming small town social drama with big, urgent themes in its bones, Leviathan finds the much needed humanity in a story of dispiriting corruption.
Men, Women & Children avoids some of the pitfalls of teen and tech focussed dramas, but is stretched thin by an overabundance of characters and concerns.
Nightcrawler is a fresh, brilliantly led crime thriller that's coated with just enough sleaze to ease consumption, and upset digestion.
Is wasting a great idea better than having none at all? It's up for debate in Cut Snake, where one smart spin on crime caper conventions just isn't enough.
Tokyo Tribe executes a wonderful idea with wild daring, amazing production values and enough rampant sexism to pretty much spoil the whole thing.
The unconventional and multidirectional approach '71 takes in exploring a moment in history more than makes up for its mixed success as an action movie.
A pair of very strong performances can't keep The Theory of Everything from succumbing to the stultifying gravity of biopic conventions.
The last ten minutes of The Cobbler are a special kind of awful. The rest is a mere disappointment coming from McCarthy, but business as usual for Sandler.
Uncomfortable truths make for brilliant cringe comedy in the gorgeous, sharply written Force Majeure.
The Humbling makes for a Thanksgiving feast, but it's Pacino who's the least hammy thing about this turkey.
Hector and the Search for Happiness is what happens when good intentions meet awful execution.
movie_title: Hector And The Search For Happiness (2014)

movie_review_blurb: If it be fated that every state eventually gets a Fargo knockoff to call its own, Montana will be disappointed that there's turned out to be as bloodless as Cut Bank.
The immigrant's struggle is brought to pulsating life in Samba, which works best as an affecting and amusing star vehicle for Omar Sy.
The Imitation Game makes a compelling case for futzing with the details of a biopic in order to get a more engaging message across.
In the face of such a weighty topic, Niccol proves a poor co-pilot for himself, as Good Kill's script fails to live up to a strong directorial effort.
Sexy, funny, beguiling, and above all, humane, The Duke of Burgundy does for erotic euro-lesbian thrillers what Under the Skin did for sci-fi.
Maybe if McFarland, or director Kriv Stenders had tried to make Kill Me Three Times half as interesting as King cast it, you wouldn't watch it feeling bored, bored, bored the whole time.
The jazzy approach takes time to settle into a groove, but the longer its themes commingle, the more Phoenix harmonizes into something unforgettable.
The Boxtrolls charms with its stunning animation and memorable assemblage of creatures and craftwork.
Like its 30-ton star, Fury can be laborious and awkward one moment, and shockingly powerful the next.
It's far from Christopher Nolan's best work, but those rare moments when Interstellar is firing on all cylinders make up for its often inert characters and shaky sentimental storytelling.
"Let's not, and say we didn't," is the only response that one should have if asked to go see Let's Be Cops.
A nicely measured start gives way to familiar, grisly action, but The Equalizer proves to be a superior breed of old man action movie.
As with Goon before it, director Michael Dowse's charmingly crude sensibilities elevate What If above the genre conventions it leans heavily on.
Less actively insensitive and insulting than its predecessor, Planes: Fire & Rescue is a slight improvement for this opportunistic, thoughtless franchise.
The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 1 often plays like a waiting game, but it solidifies the star and ideas of the franchise as the true heroes behind the YA phenomenon.

Not since Cabin in the Woods has a film so deftly toyed with audience expectations, while giving them exactly what they want. The Last Stand is a rare breed of comeback picture, a decent action movie propped up by a subversive reverence for its star.

Broken City has many good individual ideas and elements, but they never add up to a thoroughly satisfying whole. Thanks to a fine cast though, the finished product lands a bare few inches above mediocrity.
With Stoker, Park Chan-wook makes his English debut a memorably twisted horror drama, one that owes plenty to the director's best film.
G. I. Joe: Retaliation could best be described as formulaic, in that it seems like it was made from a recipe. Take two parts Bruce Willis and Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson, and mix for 100 minutes
The 108 minutes that did survive the winnowing impulses of The Weinstein Company make for a lumpy, disjointed pseudo-biopic, one that loses interest in its subject halfway through.

Prisoners isn't bringing much new to the tradition of crime thrillers and missing children horror stories, but it does speak mightily to how quality of craft separates an airplane page-turner from a minor work of pulp poetry.

The Fifth Estate rarely offers great insight into Assange or the world that spawned Wikileaks, but its acceptance of that fact makes it easier to accept as well-acted entertainment that compels you to seek out the real story.

Jason Reitman has established himself as a modern great of being consistently good, and Labor Day gives him room for the kind of leg stretching and boundary pushing that make it his most promising film to date.
Can a Song Save Your Life? is overproduced, and more than a little fake. But it carries a sweet, and catchy tune that will likely win you over
Combining the sustained tension of Bourne with the human heart of United 93, Greengrass makes Captain Phillips well worth following through the wringer.
For all its testosterone and bravado, Machete Kills won't leave you with much to remember about the film that the title doesn't already tell you.
Ender's Game is a surprisingly accessible YA adaptation that boasts a great lead performance, colourful visuals, and the toxic fingerprints of an author that might well doom the whole thing.
Tight as it might now be, Matthew McConaughey's belt is deserving of another notch thanks to the winning, but safe Dallas Buyers Club.
Thor: The Dark World leaves viewers with a fitfully enjoyable, but mostly flavorless mush to tide themselves over with until next year's offerings.
Judi Dench and Steve Coogan are a warm and winning combination in Philomena, a tale that's a little too well-spun.
A beautiful corpse of a film, Out of the Furnace is brilliantly led by Bale, but coldly executed to the point of lifelessness.
A beautifully drawn curio, The Congress often stacks its industry and tech fears too densely to provide a satisfying film experience or social commentary.
A humane triumph amid the usual summer cacophony, Dawn of the Planet of the Apes is the most intellectually and emotionally satisfying blockbuster in years.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Making the most of its shooting location, but little else, Heatstroke generates middling thrills with its underwritten, overfamiliar tale of survival.
Seeing as the musical was as ill-suited for film as Eastwood was for adapting it, it's no surprise that Jersey Boys settles for being a glorified nostalgia trip.
Without its likeable leads and occasional nuggets of insight, the pure obnoxiousness of Words and Pictures would leave you utterly speechless.
Insightful, hilarious, and filthy as all get-out, Obvious Child promises big things ahead for director Gillian Robespierre and star Jenny Slate.
Given the pedigree, a forgettably bad Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles movie is perhaps the best result anyone could have hoped for.
The entertaining Eisenberg-on-Eisenberg action makes The Double a grim delight, but it's Ayoade's work behind the camera that proves he's the one to watch.
Nastier than its predecessor in most every way, Volume II works better as the conclusion to the Nymphomaniac saga than as an individual viewing experience.
Through its first half, Nymphomaniac looks to be a darkly comic, and refreshingly blunt odyssey of smut and self-loathing.
If only every disposable action movie could be as bizarrely entertaining, and secretly insane as 3 Days to Kill is.
Good intentions and a stellar cast should amount to much more in The Monuments Men, a war picture for the aged, but not the ages.
Saving Mr. Banks uses a spoonful of sugar to force down this new history of Disney and 'Mary Poppins', but a better film would have needed just a pinch.
With a stacked cast, and sharp scripting and direction from Russell, American Hustle makes for a highly entertaining guide on how to fake it in America
Beautifully shot, well-acted, and respectful to a fault, Age of Uprising: The Legend of Michael Kohlhaas is often left inert by its weighty meditations.
movie_title: Age of Uprising: The Legend of Michael Kohlhaas (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Horrible Bosses 2 does worse than just live in the shadow of the predecessor it so slavishly imitates: it makes one doubt whether the original can still be of value if something cast from its mold can be this feeble.
Often mesmerizing and occasionally frustrating, Foxcatcher is an accomplished blend of sports-themed drama and tabloid true crime that's cool to the touch.
Like your average gallery, Night at the Museum:Secret of the Tomb is the same tour you've been on before, just with a few new visiting exhibits.
movie_title: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Unless you're after a shiftless junk pile of action movie spare parts, follow The Transporter: Refueled's advice, and don't open this package.
Pushing the YA franchise even further into sci fi B movie territory, Maze Runner: The Scorch Trials is blatantly derivative but enjoyably silly throughout.
A biting and idiosyncratic combination of romance, comedy, and body horror, The Lobster is one wonderful, oddball chimera of a movie.
Son of Saul is undoubtedly one of the most revelatory, emotionally charged, and unforgettable films 2015 has had to offer.
Thoughtfully directed and performed, Dheepan's more debatable choices don't overshadow its clear virtues.
Hitchcock/Truffaut is a snappy and informative love letter written by many different filmmakers to one great one.
Every Thing Will Be Fine is a title meant to put you at ease, but a movie that'll likely put you to sleep.
The Martian might just be an empty spacesuit underneath the science and spectacle, but it's a very entertaining one.
Where to Invade Next preaches entertainingly to its choir, but offers little in the way of actionable intelligence.
The acting, craft, and tone of Sicario are so precise that the absurdity of this cartel yarn is both its greatest weakness, and maybe its entire point.
The aesthetics and performances of The Danish Girl are powerful, but don't always come off as being in service of the artists they're meant to capture.
You'll know if Truth really has done its job if it compels you to ask questions about the history it dramatizes.
What Trumbo lacks for inspiration it makes up for with a high wattage ensemble, zippy dialogue, and unexpected modesty.
Strong casting and a bawdy sense of humour help to freshen up Lolo's stale trappings.
A Walk in the Woods takes only minimal effort to watch, and leaves you with nothing much worth remembering.
The Program streamlines Armstrong's career down to a hastily told and mostly hollow sports drama.
Like many a mother, The Meddler can be frustrating on occasion, but is worth giving your time to.
Equals may lack for inspired construction and razor-sharp plotting, but achieves moments of tactile sensuality that are rare for its genre.
Beasts of No Nation is a harshly beautiful contradiction, an unsparingly bleak portrait of war that does better than most at humanizing the people fighting it.
It's hard to imagine a scenario where James White can't be pointed to as among the best of this year's American debuts.
Sunset Song is the kind of film that makes hours in a multiplex theatre feel like curling up fireside with a good book.
It didn't seem like the phrase "it's no American Ultra" would ever be necessary, but then along comes Mr. Right.
Pan is a confounding bauble worthy of Neverland, a film with no reason to exist that will inspire obsessive rewatching to figure out how it came to be.
More Top Gun than Top Chef, Burnt is a largely insufferable character drama about one awesome dude's struggle to be even more awesome.
Though it's not a great film by any means, director Patricia Riggen extracts a fair few moments of inspiration and brilliance from the mountain of sanitized mush that is The 33.
Creed is a crowd-pleasing, franchise-extending nostalgia trip of the rarest sort: one that's not just enjoyable but inspired.
A potential vein of revisionist sex politics isn't nearly enough to warrant sitting through the drearily animated efforts of Victor Frankenstein.
As a portrait of James Dean, Life only manages to capture his soft, stolid side.
A Michael Bay with restrictions is not a Michael Bay that's particularly worth watching, as 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi illustrates.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Lovers of Austen, zombies, or half-decent genre fare will have little to feel ardent about watching Pride and Prejudice and Zombies.
Strong performances and direction allow the smartly assembled Louder Than Bombs to ring true.
Baumbach, Gerwig, and Kirke give wheel-spinning a good name with Mistress America.
The shareef won't like it, but can you blame him? Rock the Kasbah is a dreadful excuse for a comedy that will make you question your faith in Bill Murray.
Hitman: Agent 47 is sometimes as handsome as its title character, but nowhere near as capable.
No Escape starts like a coup and ends as a quagmire.
Taken 3 makes clear that the only place left for this franchise to be taken is out back, and put out of its misery.
Strange Magic isn't a good movie, but it's the kind of bad movie thats existence you can at least feel okay about.
Lazy, saccharine and (worst of all) safe, Unfinished Business is a stock image photo of what a raunchy road trip comedy is supposed to look like.
Home marks a throwback to the hyperactive, pop culture-fixated DreamWorks of old, where star power alone pushes straight-to-VOD material into theatres
High art meets lowest common denominator appeal in Woman in Gold, a tribute to one woman's struggle that has the daring and originality of a fridge magnet.
The Immigrant's handsome Blu-Ray transfer should be welcomed with open arms, even if there's little meat on the bone here for fans of special features.
Brazenly vanilla for a Sparks adaptation, The Longest Ride modestly captures the dull comfort of old-fashioned romance.
You'll wish the narrative could be as au naturel as the photography, but Monkey Kingdom makes for pleasantly diverting eco-tainment.
More bloated, but bolder than its predecessor, Avengers: Age of Ultron is every bit the 11th entry in Marvel's winning, world-dominating formula.
Small ambitions, small laughs, and small jokes define Hot Pursuit's tour through well-worn territory.
The new Poltergeist doesn't desecrate the familiar skeleton of the original, but it doesn't do a whole lot with it either.
Delightful, inventive and deeply affecting, Inside Out embodies the very best of what Pixar has to offer.
Like its four-legged hero, Max makes for a serviceable source of warm and fuzzy feelings.
A tepid romantic void at the centre of A Little Chaos will cause your enjoyment of everything else going on around it to wither.
With a steady head on its shoulders and a look as well-crafted as its lead's, The Age of Adaline is often hard to swallow but harder to dislike.
Magic Mike XXL is a softer, sweeter treat than its predecessor, but there's still no mistaking the skill applied to this prime cut meat parade.
Inconsistent and unevenly packed as it might be, American Ultra sends you off enjoying a pleasantly mellow buzz.
The dependably stunning animation from Studio Ghibli should help satisfy anyone not won over by When Marnie Was There's slight but thoughtful tale.
Ricki and the Flash is an energetic, likeable, and safe greatest hits collection for many of its talented voices.
Fantastic Four takes small steps toward reinventing the formula, and erases them in a giant leap back towards comic book movie convention.
With wit, understanding, and directorial smarts, The Diary of a Teenage Girl makes for an uncommonly loveable debut and adaptation.
movie_title: The Diary Of A Teenage Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The Gift too effectively plays possum with its first half, but the charade eventually gives way to an unexpectedly smart and twisted thriller.
Given how fun Mission: Impossible - Rogue Nation often is, it's hard to blame Paramount for squeezing every drop of momentum out of the series while it can.
The best case scenario for this film is that a director's cut eventually turns Exodus: Gods and Kings into the ambitious, personal epic it tries but mostly fails to be.
Superficial charisma and an appealing cast narrowly rescue The Man From U.N.C.L.E. from total collapse.
A strong finish does a lot to smooth out the rougher edges found in Paper Towns.
If it was the mission of Terminator Genisys to make you despair for the franchise's future, then mission accomplished.
Tired and dependent on amped up theatrics, Southpaw suggests the boxing drama genre is in as healthy a shape as the sport itself.
McKellen's performance will likely be the only evidence worth remembering of Mr. Holmes' existence.
Self/less has a lot of surprises in store, the most important being just how enjoyable and well-made it is.
Tangerine isn't without blemishes, but it rarely strikes you as anything less than a stone-cold original.

Despite its all-star cast, Big Stone Gap falls short of what it aims to be: the next great love story. There are a few notable comedic moments, however, and fans of big screen romances may find the journey worthwhile.

Overall, Hostiles was tiresome and stale. What it really comes down to is that this is not exactly the kind of movie we need right now. Yes, the film acknowledges the grotesque treatment of Native Americans, but they could have done better.
There are some strange plot holes here, which is too bad because the acting, effects, and setting were all decent.

The screenwriter for Leatherface, Seth M. Sherwood, has some explaining to do. After all, it doesn't seem likely that one little betrayal from an otherwise kind nurse could turn Jackson into Leatherface. It really doesn't make sense.
Despite its flaws, Lover for a Day is a thoughtful piece of cinema. Viewers won't be disappointed by the sympathetic narrative and will especially enjoy Garrel and Chevillotte.
movie_title: Lover For A Day (L'amant d'un jour) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Lu is a charming story filled with fantasy and childlike wonder. Flash animation is used to conjure up the magic and breathe life into the characters.
movie_title: Lu Over the Wall (Yoake tsugeru Rû no uta) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: If you love your mother, do not make her see this movie.
Dano and Radcliffe's performances are an absolute delight.
Quickly fizzles out when it becomes apparent that what's being shown on-screen is less than necessary to the story's development.
movie_title: Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Despite its length and less than satisfying story, Phantom Boy excels in its artistry and craft
Although the story falters its way to the end, Miss Peregrine's technical aspects manage to intrigue you enough to make it worthwhile.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The Little Prince is a beautiful tribute to a timeless book.
The technicalities, animation, and effort behind the film prove that this past summer movie season wasn't a total flop.

What the film lacks in flash it makes up for in cinematography. What could have been a very plain-looking film with its flat, dusty lands is beautifully captured with wide shots and a breathtaking yellow and blue color palette.
The Lobster wonderfully kick-starts a new year in movies with its breathtaking cinematography, performances, score, and storyline. Although it has a male lead, the film's story is driven by women.
Fits and Starts is a hilarious interpretation of modern artistry.
The Handmaiden is a captivating and beautiful story of two underestimated women manipulating the manipulators.

Maggie's Plan highlights Moore's comedic capabilities, which we unfortunately don't get to see very often. And Gerwig proves that her quirky attitude is not limited to one role but can change and morph to showcase her talents.
At only 72 minutes, My Entire High School Sinking Into the Sea manages to undo and examine more teen angst than you would expect from an animated, coming of age, disaster movie.
movie_title: My Entire High School Sinking Into the Sea (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Wind River provides all of the essentials of an exciting thriller while calling attention to an unspoken problem in need of addressing.
If you're looking for an inspirational boost this December, The Post is a good place to start.
Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool is a rich romance that mixes Old Hollywood with new.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: What the film lacks in thoroughness though, it makes up for in humor, cute creatures, and marine life fun facts.
Taraji P. Henson, Octavia Spencer and Janelle Monáe bring every ounce of their considerable charm to a script filled with humor and heart.
What more could a kid -- or a grown-up who's seen too many overly serious superhero movies -- ask for?

It's movies like The Normal Heart, fuelled by the performances within it, that make you want to learn more and provide perspective on one of the bleakest times for the gay community. That, and increase Kleenex sales at Costco.
If you can get over the pretentious and stuffy first half of the film, you will be rewarded with a rather unique experience.
There are some good monster moments that, with more build up, would have been startling. We want to see more action, we don't want to read about it or hear people talk about it.
Kopacka ends the film with ambiguity; he manages to show you everything without showing anything. It's simple and that's what makes this film so beautiful to watch.

Despite its innovative direction and talented cast, Grease: Live fell victim to its bland source material - and equally bland leads - leaving it unable to truly top other iterations of the modern TV musical.

While it may not be enough to renew every musical-lover's faith in live-to-TV performances, The Wiz Live! certainly proves that musicals have a place on television right now - and not just in late-night monologue jokes.
A single father who is cynical and miserly at first, the cabby emerges as a delightful and layered protagonist after an impressive character arc, thanks to director Jang Hoon's superb storytelling.
While Hawkins and the supporting cast give great performances, Shannon steals the show.
While Dench's performance is convincing, there is a distinct lack of chemistry between the pair.
Epic and poignant.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Its action scenes are let down by the poor graphics and cringey acting. As for the romantic storyline, it is cliched and forced, and ends predictably.
While both actors' performances are convincing, their characters are bland.
Neo's acting is passable but most of the characters are cringe-inducing caricatures.
movie_title: Wonderful! Liang Xi Mei the Movie (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Braven is a visceral film that is heartening despite its chilling brutality, as it showcases the sacrifices one would make to protect the ones who truly matter - family.

Admittedly, it takes a certain level of patience to appreciate Last Flag Flying's slow pace - a tall order for the mainstream audience. Yet, it is a fair trade if you can admire its earnest tone that is visceral and truly hits home.
After seeing Cosmopolis, you're going to want to take a shower.
As endearing and funny as Keanu can be, it feels like a Key & Peele sketch that's stretched out to a full-length film.
Both a sobering deconstruction of the financial crisis and a surprisingly entertaining film.

Two reasons not to go see Abduction: first, every screening is guaranteed to be jam-packed with rabid girls squealing every time its star, Twilight's Taylor Lautner is on screen. Second: it's just not a good movie.
This is pure popcorn entertainment, a one-dimensional outing that is more in the ballpark of Thor and Fantastic Four than anything else.
A one-dimensional but amusing sugar rush of a movie.
Thor is a really good popcorn flick -- just a little too bloated in places to hit the mark as well as it could have.
The Dark Knight Rises is an intense and brutal viewing experience, easily the most emotionally exhausting of the three films.
The standard talking-heads-and-archive-footage doc this is not.
movie_title: SHOT!: The Psycho-Spiritual Mantra of Rock (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A fantastically observed, occasional hilarious look at our clumsy paths to creative fulfilment.
With a truly unique script, definitive characterization, and plenty of surprises, Toni Erdmann is among the most enthralling and moving cinema of the year.
For all its clinical detachment, Glazer's film becomes its own oblique treatise on what it means to be and feel human.
Weekend is finally a deeply romantic film, assured of the pleasure that one person can find in another, but rooted in the quirks and textures of contemporary British life.

Cuarón co-wrote his father Alfonso's Gravity, and if the direction in Desierto is skilful more than truly inspired, he more than proves his ability to ratchet up the tension for a breathless survival drama of his own.

Frears' film doesn't attempt to dig up anything new or profound so much as zip entertainingly round the twists and turns of an episode of recent sporting villainy whose fascination happily survives the retelling.
This thought-provoking film remains a key work by Scorsese, a courageous and imaginative take on one of the greatest stories ever told.
Luhrmann's flamboyant direction pumps new life into a well-known, much-adapted tale.
Successfully gets to the heart of the obsessions that drive great writers -- and will have you dusting down your old school copy of the 'Lyrical Ballads'!
A dark, intelligent, and thought-provoking examination of female repression.
Quote not available.
Mohsen successfully merges fiction and fact to produce some astonishing imagery.
movie_title: Kandahar: Le soleil derrière la lune (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
Rivette's examination of the nature of relationships is witty and light-hearted.
Merchant effectively translates Naipaul's lively mix of characters from the page to screen.
Quote not available.
A gem made in the 'Golden Age' of Indian cinema.
The slow pace can make it tedious to watch at times, but for Ray, allowances should be made.
Nair doesn't treat the issues lightly. She allows each character to confront their problems openly and honestly.
Not enough bright spots in disappointing adaptation.
Occasionally violent origin story is surprisingly good.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Overly crude body-swapping comedy isn't for kids.
Poignant, thought-provoking Civil Rights tale.
Positive messages can't save worst film in action series.
movie_title: Spy Kids: All the Time in the World in 4D (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Uneven coming-of-age drama features sex, drugs, adultery.
Great actors and good messages, but very predictable plot.
Fantastic family drama features intense martial-arts fights.
Cool but predictable sci-fi Western has lots of violence.
'Greatest hits' show is tame enough for tween Gleeks.
Insightful docu features thousands of YouTube clips.
Slightly better than No. 2, but still crude and very violent.
Spectacularly epic, poignant end to a magical series.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Clocking in at a zippy 63 minutes, the story is precisely the right length for squirmy tots and concludes before the minimal plot grows stale for adults.
Pointless comedy is a waste of a talented comedic cast.
Collection of unmemorable holiday shorts but fun DVD extras.
Silly but sweet travel comedy says to be true to yourself.
Educational but slow docu may not keep kids' interest.
Slow but insightful documentary about pioneering activist.
Cars sequel revs up action and mixes in spy thrills.
Carrey's penguin antics are predictable but still funny.
Popular book heroine gets a bummer adaptation.
movie_title: Judy Moody and the NOT Bummer Summer (2011)

movie_review_blurb: With summer comes theaters filled with superheroes, sequels and forgettable family fare. In the last category, we find "Judy Moody."
movie_title: Judy Moody and the NOT Bummer Summer (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Adorable big-screen Pooh adaptation is short and sweet.
Touching nature docu gets too emotional for littlest kids.
Tame girls' basketball tale is sentimental but inspiring.
Underwhelming action thriller has deaths, violence.
Occasionally violent sequel emphasizes love over status.
Quirky animated comedy follows a family's ups and downs.
Streep is riveting in well-acted but underwhelming biopic.
Spielberg's sweeping horse drama is beautiful but intense.
Whirlwind animated adventure is a visual treat for tweens.
Silly threequel is full of pop-culture references and jokes.
Scathingly funny 'mean girl' story has lots of drinking.
So-so tween riches-to-rags story has positive lesson.
Hill's misadventures are crazy and crass but still funny.
Fabulous, funny holiday movie about the Christmas spirit.
Muppet comedy offers memorable laughs, musical numbers.
Heartwarming tale is sweet, inspiring for kids and tweens.
Spectacular book adaptation is great for tweens and up.
Sexy honeymoon, disturbing pregnancy dominate latest movie.
Few laughs in crude, kid-targeted Sandler comedy.
Despite violence, Christian fatherhood drama is uplifting.
Swashbuckling adventure features irresistible warrior cat.
Sci-fi thriller has violence, sexuality, language.
Swashbuckler for tweens has tons of action but no heart.
Amateurish animation mars Christian animal tale about Jesus.
Slapstick-heavy spoof features dumbed-down humor for tweens.
Remake is surprisingly fresh but still faithful to original.
Uplifting docu spotlights legendary high school jazz band.
Raunchy romcom promotes double standards, stereotypes.
Penguin sequel has fun musical numbers, a few mild scares.
More swashbuckling + less violence = OK for older tweens.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: "African Cats" prefers less preaching and more heartstring-tugging. It works, of course, especially if you're trying to raise your own cubs to adulthood.
Sweet, funny wedding comedy is a good parent-and-teen pick.
Great movie, but not appropriate for all kids.
Clever Sherlock Holmes tribute mixes wit, peril.
BBC's 5-part series shows a feisty, moody, realistic Anne.
Great Whitney Houston songs, mediocre love story.
Docu is the best introduction to the Holocaust for tweens.
Ghost-lite romantic comedy is only so-so.
Sandaled Python pic too irreverent for young kids.
Animated indie explores unusual friendship, heavy themes.
Powerful, kid-friendly intro to black history stories.
movie_title: March On! The Day My Brother Martin Changed the World (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Leftover, lesser stunts from Jackass crew.
LOTR copycat is so bad it's good -- for laughs.
movie_title: In the Name of the King: A Dungeon Siege Tale (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Wizard of Oz spoof stands in as prodigal son tale.
movie_title: VeggieTales: The Wonderful Wizard of Ha's (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Well-acted war drama is too intense for kids.
Wild West-themed final installment is fine for older tweens.
movie_title: Back to the Future Part III (1990)

movie_review_blurb: Star-studded stage musical harder for young kids to follow.
Touching, beautiful drama about the magic of friendship.
Amusing adventure for fans of Jack Black and silly jokes.
Dumber-than-average family comedy won't even impress kids.
Techie reboot is visually dazzling but short on story.
Romantic thriller has some mature twists.
Engaging third Narnia adventure is fun for tweens and up.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Adorable real pandas but otherwise sappy animal adventure.
Fantastic princess adventure is fun, with great messages.
Forgettable fish-out-of-water movie has disturbing scene.
The first Anderson/Wilson offbeat, talky comedy.
Inspiring true story has some violent wartime flashbacks.
Cute Huck Finn parody teaches kids to help others.
Sentimental Depression-era Christmas story is fine for kids.
movie_title: 12 Dogs of Christmas: Great Puppy Rescue (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Soap-operaish romcom is full of mature twists, betrayals.
Unrealistic prom flick is bland for teens, fine for tweens.
Fairy tale sequel has tired jokes, tedious references.
She's a conformist overachiever, he's a troubled soul; a third-grader could tell that the two will fall hard for each other by the movie's halfway point.
Magical realism adventure promotes family, environmentalism.
movie_title: Mia et le Migou (Mia and the Migoo) (2011)
