Goosebumps is a fun, if frantic, scary adventure for kids that even captures the spirit of R.L. Stine's original books.
Pan falls short at being either an imaginative origin story for Peter Pan and/or a satisfying standalone big-budget fantasy adventure.
The Walk is an entertaining and often thrilling piece of storytelling, in addition to being an impressive display of 3D filmmaking.
The Intern is an insubstantial Nancy Meyers comedy kept afloat by Robert De Niro and Anne Hathaway's screen chemistry.
Pawn Sacrifice is an engaging and well-made biopic with solid performances, but fails at being an insightful and thematically rich work of cinema.
Z for Zachariah uses its post-apocalyptic backdrop to craft a compelling and moody character study.
Despite some competent suspenseful filmmaking, a thin story and xenophobic overtones make No Escape an unpleasant movie to watch.
There are elements of a decent horror parable here, but Sinister 2 lacks the restrained direction and eery mythos of its predecessor.
Ricki and the Flash is a half-baked comedy/drama, but the cast (including Meryl Streep's aging rocker) makes it a charming one.
Mission: Impossible - Rogue Nation is a smart and exciting blockbuster, as well as another strong installment in the Tom Cruise action franchise.
Sets a new bar for big and splashy comic book blockbusters; unfortunately, while The Amazing Spider-Man 2 is enthralling, in the end, it's also pretty empty.
Southpaw is a paint by numbers boxing drama kept afloat by good direction and a ferocious Jake Gyllenhaal performance.
Mr. Holmes is a solid (if unremarkable) period drama that is anchored by a great Ian McKellen performance as an old Sherlock Holmes
Minions delivers just enough of what people love about the eponymous Despicable Me characters to please their fanbase - but not much else.
Magic Mike XXL may not be an insightful continuation of its predecessor, but it delivers an experience that many wanted the first time around
Jurassic World is a big, shiny, and entertaining roller coaster ride, though the 'World' is more interesting than the people.
Spy is a very good showcase for Melissa McCarthy and another successful collaboration between her and director Paul Feig.
Aloha has elements of Cameron Crowe's best work, but poor storytelling results in a film that's more perplexing than charming.
Hot Pursuit will provide some moviegoers with a few easy laughs, but others are likely to find it just boring and unfunny.
The Age of Adaline is a ludicrous romantic fantasy, but solid craftsmanship and good acting make it an enjoyable one too.
Die-hard Kevin James fans will get additional mileage from it, but Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2 is a pretty easy pass for everyone else.
Furious 7 is another solid Fast and the Furious installment - one that (flaws aside) provides a nice farewell to star Paul Walker.
The film might not be as deep as it aspires to be, but It Follows is one retro horror movie that's quite creepy and has style to spare.
McFarland, USA is by-the-numbers underdogs sport fare, but good direction and performances make it a respectable addition to the genre.
Seventh Son would be utterly forgettable, were it not for some decent directorial elements and the performances of Jeff Bridges and Julianne Moore.
It's far from ground-breaking in its social statements, but Black or White is still a solid comedy/drama buoyed by good performances all around.
Even fans of the series should wait until they can see Haunted House 2 at home - where they can take as many verbal potshots at its awfulness as they like.
Black Nativity is ungainly in execution, yet still infused with enough passion and reverence for Hughes' original work to be more success than failure.
Plays out as a farce that (sadly) just isn't all that insightful, witty, or creative with how it approaches its premise - one that is kind of funny but only goes so far.
A slight improvement on its predecessor but also the cinematic equivalent of a cynical studio executive's checklist of items that need to be included in a Smurf movie.
The Wolverine ranks among the better X-Men (as well as comic book) movies - even though its artistic compromises prevent it from reaching greatness.
Turbo is a harmless underdog story for kids with well-executed racing sequences but a flat approach to characterization and unchallenging life lessons.
Despite committed and charming performances from the cast, The Way, Way Back is little more than a run-of-the-mill addition to the coming-of-age genre.
Those who adore the Minions and want more light-hearted fun in the zany Despicable Me universe should get what they are looking for in the sequel.
Much of The Heat's success can be credited to Melissa McCarthy and while the film offers a fair amount of belly-laughs it also includes plenty of missed opportunities.
Monsters University is as spiritually-uplifting and pleasant as the original but isn't as strong a creative accomplishment - unlikely to be as well-remembered.
This is the End is an outrageously crude (and low-brow) raunch-com that lampoons an eclectic mixture and wide range of pop-culture targets, often to very funny effect.
If you're interested in a suave demonstration of cinematic showmanship (no more, but no less), then you might want to consider giving Now You See Me a look.
By-the-numbers kid's movie elements prevent Epic from completely living up to its name; nonetheless, it's still a solid film for the whole family.
The Big Wedding is an occasionally charming and, overall, strangely watchable variation in the dysfunctional wedding comedy subgenre.
An overly-preposterous, neo-Noir crime thriller that unravels its central mystery - and then collapses when bringing deeper significance to the proceedings.
A divisive work of art, Spring Breakers is an audacious, yet enthralling and even transcendent, portrait of maturity sprouting from a place of corruption and avarice.
The Spectacular Now forgoes easy wistfulness in favor of untidy human emotion - as grounded in the compassionate and engaging turns by the film's leads.
21 and Over won't go down as generation-defining but its target demographic should find something to laugh at.
Stand Up Guys gets caught up in stereotypical old-timer laughs but its principal cast shakes them off and ultimately makes the experience fulfilling.
Short on standard Statham action, Parker is an unremarkable but (mostly) satisfactory crime tale worth checking out.
There's no reason to reward or encourage any of the people involved with A Haunted House to continue making this type of off-putting (and disposable) raunch-fest.
Promised Land is high-minded material - but makes for a flaccid viewing experience.
Parental Guidance is a lightweight piece of family-friendly fluff in every meaning of the phrase.
There's really little reason to check out Monsters, Inc. 3D in... well, 3D, rather than going for a good old-fashioned 2D screening instead.
Hitchcock gets points for being more ambitious than your average tried-and-true Hollywood memoir - even if it's only moderately successful in that task.
Wright's rendition of Anna Karenina is indeed flawed but the rich performances, succinct screenwriting, and strong direction make it a re-interpretation worth seeing.
The Sessions resembles one of O'Brien's poems (which are featured in the story) - neither flawless nor ever-graceful in terms of technique but still gentle and sincere.
A funny, touching, and occasionally-shaky tale, with some sermonizing thrown in for good measure.
Chasing Mavericks offers some spectacular cinematic imitation of the surfing experience, but fills that mold with paint-by-numbers plot beats and characters.
Borrows so liberally from other movies that it could have been fascinating, but due to confused direction and a mishmash of acting, it's ultimately bland and forgettable.
movie_title: House at the End of the Street (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Secret in Their Eyes is a well-acted and politically-charged drama/thriller with ambitions that exceed its grasp.
Escape from Planet Earth's flaws would be more forgivable if the film offered better fun for younger viewers.
Young moviegoers will enjoy large segments of Planes but it's difficult to ignore that the film is little more than an (often) dull and nearly-soulless cash grab.
Lee Daniels' The Butler  is part lackluster biopic, part ham-fisted (and somewhat misguided) historical allegory - despite noble intentions of the cast and filmmakers.
There's enough innovation and enthusiasm for the horror genre present in You're Next to make it worth recommending to gore-hounds and hardcore horror lovers.
A wondrous celebration of everything that Wes Anderson holds dear - while moving farther away from being a universally recommendable title for casual viewers.
3 Days to Kill offers little substance that hasn't been handled more effectively in previous Luc Besson directed Euro-action/thrillers.
Despite an often muddled story, the meaningful fantasy yarn about life and love in Winter's Tale will at least leave viewers with something to mull over afterwards.
Vampire Academy will likely only satisfy fans of the books. To most everyone else, it's another disposable addition to the growing pile of cheap YA movie adaptations.
Labor Day is a sincere and earnest attempt to get at the deeper meaning of a rather soapy premise; unfortunately, the movie is only partially successful in its quest.
Gimme Shelter feels like the final result of a C-grade director having watched Precious and deciding that he could do better.
Nut Job is a decent (but entirely forgettable) animated crime/caper for younger audiences.
Occasionally satisfying and funny, but mostly just watered-down action/comedy tropes and uninspired slapstick - all less imaginative than similar buddy cop movie offerings.
Legend of Hercules feels like a glorified Syfy movie that lacks the cheekiness necessary to make the whole experience a so-bad-it's-good B-movie viewing.
Grudge Match has just enough thoughtfulness and emotional perceptiveness to make up for the many cliche elements - offering decent but unremarkable entertainment value.
A solid memoir in its scope, scale and respectful (yet critically-objective) tone; but as biographical cinema, is far less revolutionary than its subject.
American Hustle offers a, crowd-pleasing experience - one with profound social commentary, laugh-out-loud comedy, and even unexpected moments of compassion to boot.
Walking with Dinosaurs unfolds like a decent 3D documentary screened at a museum theater - which ultimately makes it a C-grade theatrical feature.
Frozen is a fine addition to Disney's animated pantheon, offering a witty and heartfelt princess fairly tale with creative musical elements and visual panache.
Dench and Coogan are the beating heart of Philomena, which despite a few storytelling flaws, ultimately presents a stirring and enjoyable moviegoing experience.
Nebraska is an engaging, funny and altogether touching road trip that moviegoers of different ages might want to consider taking.
Dallas Buyers Club works best as a showcase for McConaughey and Leto's great performances - not so much as a thoughtful examination of historical issues.
Free Birds has neither the heart nor the necessary spark of artistic madness, to make up for its perfunctory story design.
12 Years a Slave doesn't add much to the ongoing conversation about slavery but it's a well-made meditation about a man who endures a terrifying journey.
A noble-minded, but only partly successful film - one that will probably be a riveting moviegoing experience for some, but an unsatisfying trip across the ocean for others.
Of course Machete Kills is supposed to be "bad," but it's also supposed to be entertainingly dumb and loony - which is where it falls short.
Good casting and lovely production values but stilted execution - considering Romeo and Juliet is supposed to feel like the most powerful tragic romance tale ever told.
By the end, Parkland does little more than exploit JFK's murder through a cinematic recreation - one that fails to shed new light or insight.
Metallica Through the Never succeeds as an enthralling and visceral concert movie experience but fails to use the medium for a deeper level of artistic appreciation.
A harmless romance-fantasy that avoids normal rom-com gender double-standards, misogyny, and/or misandry - but with gooey life-lessons that are only partly earned.
There's not nearly enough quality material to make Battle of the Year recommendable to anyone other than the most hard-core of dance fanatics.
The good elements outweigh the bad in Thanks for Sharing and the final result is a commendable examination of addiction, sex and the nature of grown-up relationships.
The Family offers a solid blend of dark satire, social commentary, off-beat humor, quirky aesthetics, and a decent (albeit unremarkable) amount of substance.
The direction is so amateurish that Getaway fails to even provide serviceable B-movie thrills.
Enjoyable music and traces of authentic Brazilian spirit provide reasonable compensation for Rio 2's derivative qualities and storytelling flaws (if only barely so).
The Good Dinosaur isn't as sophisticated as Disney/Pixar's best films, but still boasts a touching story and gorgeous animation.
Full of intriguing concepts and potential, but by the end much of that promise goes unfulfilled - with the film as a whole nearly sliding off the rails in the process.
Brooklyn is a beautiful period drama and rich piece of romantic storytelling that boasts great performances.
The Emoji Movie squanders the talents of its capable voice cast on an animated film that is as cynical in its outlook as it was in its conception.
Dunkirk makes for Christopher Nolan's most intense and nerve-wracking thriller yet, delivering a strikingly terse viewing experience in the process.
Rich in emotional honesty and equal parts funny/moving, The Big Sick successfully infuses the traditional rom-com formula with a modern sensibility.
Spider-Man: Homecoming works as both a (very) funny high school comedy/drama and strong standalone superhero movie set in the MCU.
Despicable Me 3 offers enough in the way of zany, irreverent entertainment (with a dose of heart) to please steadfast fans of the franchise.
War for the Planet of the Apes is as satisfying a conclusion to Caesar's journey as it is a compelling standalone, big-budget blockbuster experience.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Transformers: The Last Knight has a deeper mythos and bigger spectacle than its predecessors, yet still ends up being mostly hollow and cacophonous.
The Book of Henry awkwardly mashes together compelling individual elements, giving rise to a jarring and otherwise confounding viewing experience.
Cars 3 offers more heartfelt storytelling and rich animation than its predecessor, yet falls short of raising the bar for the Cars franchise.
Alien: Covenant plays it safe by mashing together the best elements of previous Alien films, delivering a solid sci-fi horror/thriller in the process.
Legend of the Sword's brazen reimagining of Arthurian mythos, coupled with Ritchie's style, makes for a bombastic yet entertaining King Arthur epic.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 doubles-down on everything that audiences loved about its predecessor, to still-entertaining but diminished returns.
The Lost City of Z is a handsome and ambitious historical epic, if also one that's more intellectually engaging than emotionally compelling.
Detroit makes for a disturbing and unnerving portrayal of real historical events, but has less success as a work of sociopolitical commentary.
The Fate of the Furious is a solid addition to the franchise, but falls short of the bar set by recent Fast & Furious installments.
Ghost in the Shell struggles to dig below the surface of its thought-provoking concepts and bring real depth to its striking visuals.
Despite some promising elements, Life amounts to a middling (and derivative) sci-fi horror/thriller that never fully realizes its potential.
Power Rangers has mixed success with its efforts to modernize the franchise, but offers enough playful storytelling and spectacle to offset its flaws.
Kong: Skull Island is a shared universe launchpad that fulfills its promise of big, goofy, monster mayhem - setting up even bigger things to come.
Beauty and the Beast does right by its predecessor, delivering a musical experience that both dazzles the eyes and plucks the heartstrings.
X-Men movie franchise connections aside, Logan is a grisly and somber character drama that sends off Hugh Jackman's Wolverine on a high note.
Fist Fight may be as slight as a half-hour sitcom comedy, but enough of its R-Rated jokes hit their target to sustain the movie's brisk runtime.
The Great Wall is an odd mashup of Hollywood monster blockbuster and sweeping Chinese fantasy epic.
While Fifty Shades Darker exceeds its predecessor in some ways, in other respects it's just as ridiculous (if not more so) by comparison.
The LEGO Batman Movie works as not only a funny riff on the Batman character and his legacy, but also as a great action/comedy on its own terms.
The Final Chapter meets the standard for mindless thrills set by the previous Resident Evil films, ending the series on more of a shrug than a bang.
Split is the best M. Night Shyamalan creation in recent memory, as anchored by a great performance (or, rather, performances) by James McAvoy.
Patriots Day is more effective as a suspense thriller than a stirring docudrama that explores the complexities of real-life heroism.
The Lost Village is standard, kid-friendly entertainment, but it succeeds at bringing the colorful Smurfs universe to playfully-animated life.
Silence is beautifully-crafted and well-acted, but often frustrating in the way that it examines spirituality through historical drama.
Wind River is a decent, if flawed, directorial effort from Sheridan that showcases his strength as an actors' director, more than as a writer.
American Assassin is a preposterous, but lean and mean Mitch Rapp thriller adaptation elevated by Michael Keaton's turn as Rapp's grizzled mentor.
The Light of the Moon delves into the messy realities of the emotional and physical fallout of rape, giving rise to a moving yet sensitive drama.
Despite some promising elements, Mute struggles to explore philosophical questions within a sci-fi setting in a way that feels innovative and fresh.
Anchored by Jennifer Lawrence's performance, Red Sparrow is a slow-burn spy/seductress thriller that's shiny on the surface, yet lacking in depth.
Black Panther is a great MCU superhero adventure that smoothly blends rich narrative substance with sheer popcorn entertainment.
The Cloverfield Paradox is a disjointed, but enjoyable sci-fi horror/thriller that has mixed success as a shared universe film.
Winchester is a bland horror film that avoids being altogether forgettable thanks to leads Helen Mirren and Jason Clarke.
Hostiles is grim and slow-burn to a fault in its deconstruction of the American West's violent legacy, but strong performances keep the film on track.
Phantom Thread is another gorgeous fever dream of a film by Anderson, with Day-Lewis' powerhouse performance matched by his costar Vicky Krieps' here.
The Commuter is a goofy and formulaic thriller, but also an entertaining one thanks to Neeson's action star chops and Collet-Serra's sense of style.
Paddington 2 is a charming confection of a film that manages to exceed its predecessor in terms of both visual splendor and good-natured storytelling.
Insidious: The Last Key is a solid finale to the Insidious franchise that gives series lead Lin Shaye the chance to take a graceful final bow.
Bright is a muddled mess of a film that fails to produce any fresh concepts or creative ideas by mashing together two distinctly different genres.
All the Money in the World makes for a solid dramatic thriller, but falls short when it comes to being an insightful biopic about John Paul Getty.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Good Time's inspired style, coupled with Pattinson's compelling performance, are enough to carry the film past its narrative shortcomings.

This gives rise to a larger tonal issue that weakens the film's otherwise solid narrative, as Goodbye Christopher Robin tries to spin a heartwarming story out of one that is more heartbreaking and poignant.
Three Billboards wobbles during its tightrope walk between comedy and drama, but is kept on-course by careful direction and two fiery performances.
Lady Bird makes for a delightful coming of age comedy/drama, fueled by Gerwig's inspired direction and Saoirse Ronan's charming performance.
Justice League successfully ushers in a new era for DC Films and delivers lots of superhero fun - at the expense of a richer and more layered movie.
Thelma makes for an effectively moody and evocative piece of Norwegian-flavored filmmaking, even as it brings more groundbreaking stories to mind.
Blade of the Immortal lacks depth as a quest for redemption narrative, but makes for good (and very bloody) pulpy fun in Miike's skillful hands.
movie_title: Blade of the Immortal (Mugen no jûnin) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Thank You for Your Service isn't a great piece of filmmaking, but good intentions and sincere performances make it a solid drama about life after war.
Only the Brave makes for a straightforward, but meaningful salute to real-world heroism, thanks to its strong performances and sturdy direction.
While there are elements of a riveting Swedish Noir thriller here, The Snowman proves to be more of a pulpy mess than a chilling crime tale.
Marshall is a solid courtroom melodrama elevated by Boseman's towering performance and its own timely-as-ever subject matter.
Our advice: this is one game that you should take the time to play.
American Made is a conventional true story crime caper that stays afloat thanks to Liman's solid direction and Cruise's committed turn as an antihero.
Blade Runner 2049 not only succeeds at feeling like a necessary franchise revival, it also makes for a captivating standalone work of science-fiction.
Battle of the Sexes thrives as a crowd-pleasing sports story with charm to spare, even as it sugarcoats the real-life events that inspired it.
Welcome to the Jungle is an entertaining - if shallow - return to the world of Jumanji that's intended more for youngsters than nostalgic adults.
Hidden Figures is the rare true story-based historical drama that succeeds at being as inspirational and feel-good as it aspires to be.
As a coming of age parable, IT succeeds at being both horrifying and emotionally-resonant, even while adapting only half of King's original story.
Victor Frankenstein is an entertainingly kooky, but otherwise messy and slapdash re-imagining of the Frankenstein mythos, for these reasons.
The Nice Guys is an entertainingly breezy buddy-detective romp that steadfast Shane Black fans ought to get additional mileage from.
Money Monster is a well-directed and well-acted dramatic thriller weighed down by heavy-handed social commentary and implausible plot beats.
Captain America: Civil War is a great superhero blockbuster that lays the groundwork for even bigger and better things to come in Phase 3 of the MCU.
Keanu may be a glorified feature-length Key and Peele skit, but it's also an entertaining and thematically-layered action/comedy parody.
Despite a fun performance from Kevin Costner, Criminal is a half-baked action/thriller that fails to properly explore its sci-fi premise.
The Boss isn't a mold-breaker for Melissa McCarthy's brand of humor, but it is a solid mainstream comedy elevated by its star.
Hardcore Henry is only partly successful at using the first person POV format to create a unique cinematic experience.
It's not exactly a bar-raising sequel, but My Big Fat Greek Wedding 2 has enough of its predecessor's charm and sincerity to earn a passing grade.
Allegiant is a subpar installment in The Divergent Series that fails to justify the decision to split the final Divergent novel into two movies.
The Brothers Grimsby is a middle of the road action/comedy where Sacha Baron Cohen's R-Rated comedy brand offers diminishing returns.
Whiskey Tango Foxtrot is an uneven, but otherwise passable wartime comedy/drama anchored by Tina Fey's performance.
London Has Fallen is an uninspired sequel to Olympus Has Fallen, but has some of its predecessor's cheesy action movie throwback charm.
Triple 9 has elements of greatness, but its talented cast and inspired directorial flourishes are offset by messy storytelling choices.
Alice Through the Looking Glass is more of a shiny, yet hollow, Disney product than meaningful continuation of Alice's story.
Gods of Egypt is a cheesy and visually unimpressive fantasy adventure that's too dull to make for fun campy entertainment.
Zealander 2 aims to be bigger and crazier than its predecessor, but amounts to a serviceable (though less memorable) comedy sequel.
How to Be Single relies heavily on rom-com tropes, but succeeds in putting a more thoughtful and funny spin on many of them.
Hail, Caesar! is a funny and madcap, if unfocused, farcical salute to Golden Age Hollywood from the Coen Brothers.
The Finest Hours is a respectful dramatization of the real-life events that inspired it, but is too by the numbers to leave a strong impression.
13 Hours has elements of a lean and efficient action/thriller, but is bloated and overblown thanks to Michael Bay's directorial approach.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Ride Along 2 is an uninspired retread of its predecessor, but manages to reach the (low) bar set for this action/comedy franchise.
Carol is a visually rich period drama that boasts strong performances and refined direction, though some may find it easier to admire than love.
Sisters is an uneven mix of raunchy farce and sincerity that's elevated by the undeniable chemistry between Tina Fey and Amy Poehler.
Joy is a decent biographical drama anchored by Jennifer Lawrence's performance, but fails to realize its greater ambitions.
The Big Short has its flaws, but is one of the more unique movies based on non-fiction literature in recent memory
Daddy's Home is a formulaic Will Ferrell comedy, but enough jokes hit their mark to make it a passable one, when all is said and done.
Macbeth is an effectively grim and well-acted Shakespeare adaptation, but prioritizes style over substance.
Krampus isn't as clever or scary as Christmas horror/comedies past, but provides enough kitschy fun for those craving a darker holiday yarn.
The Witch is effectively unpleasant and creepy, but it works better as a psychological thriller than a horror film.
The Conjuring 2 isn't as innovative a horror film throwback as its predecessor, it's an excellent ghost story in its own right.
Popstar: Never Stop Never Stopping is essentially a solid Lonely Island sketch over-stretched to fill a feature-length running time.
Queen of Katwe is a heavy-handed variation of the Disney inspirational sports drama formula, but a sincere and well-meaning one too.

Anchored by the two great performances from its leads, terrific musical numbers and stylish direction, La La Land is a proper crowd-pleaser and a heartfelt salute to old Hollywood that harkens back to the past in order to create something fresh.
Sing is a narratively slight, but energetic animated musical romp that succeeds in staying light on its toes throughout its running time.
Manchester by the Sea is an affecting examination of the grieving process, brought to life through strong direction and compelling performances.
Nocturnal Animals has style and ambition to spare, yet as a whole Tom Ford's dark psychological thriller rings hollow.
Allied is most compelling as a dramatic spy thriller - less so as a sweeping romance that unfolds against the backdrop of WWII.
Moana is a funny, heartfelt and richly-crafted hero's journey adventure that effectively puts a Disney spin on Southern Pacific culture
The Edge of Seventeen captures the spirit of classic John Hughes comedies - at the same time, refining and innovating Hughes' storytelling approach.
Moonlight is one of the most poignant, poetic and beautiful movies of the year.
Arrival is a smart tale of alien contact that boasts great visuals and performances, if also more brains than heart.
Hacksaw Ridge is a grisly WWII movie that excels as an action/thriller, but has mixed success in realizing its loftier thematic ambitions.
Thanks to the efforts of its talented cast and crew, Ouija: Origin of Evil is more solid horror film than soulless franchise continuation.
The Birth of a Nation is a work of passion-fueled filmmaking and messy storytelling that struggles to make the grand statement it aims for.
Deepwater Horizon effectively turns the real-world disaster into an action/drama that's more disturbing than thrilling to watch.
Although not a disaster, Masterminds is a disposable and middling off-kilter heist comedy that squanders its cast's talents on subpar material.
Kevin Hart and Dwayne Johnson's comedic chemistry save Central Intelligence from being a passable, yet forgettable, mainstream action/comedy.
Fences struggles to make the leap from the stage to the big screen, but is kept afloat by the powerhouse performances of its leads.
Sully amounts to a respectable yet unmemorable account of real-life heroism, despite fine performances and capable direction.
Free State of Jones is well-crafted and tells a worthwhile story, but makes for a better history lesson than moviegoing experience.
The Neon Demon is a stylishly surreal, but hollow, horror/thriller - and another Nicolas Winding Refn film bound to divide audiences.
There's a great Tarzan adventure somewhere in Legend of Tarzan, but the movie is too overstuffed and rough around the edges to fly high.
Steven Spielberg's The BFG is a technically impressive adaptation of Roald Dahl's novel - one with whimsy and heart to spare.
Bridget Jones's Baby is a perfectly enjoyable addition to the Bridget Jones franchise, if not a particularly meaningful one.
The Infiltrator is a stylishly crafted and well-acted dramatic thriller, but breaks little new ground despite fascinating subject matter.
The Secret Life of Pets isn't a mold-breaker for animated movies, but it's a consistently funny and inspired madcap romp nonetheless.
Jason Bourne is a serviceable Bourne franchise installment, but an uninventive and unnecessary epilogue to the original Bourne movie trilogy.
Pete's Dragon succeeds as a dramatic reimagining of its predecessor - giving rise to a soulful modern fairy tale in the process.
Wars Dogs is a solid movie, but only partly succeeds at blending Todd Phillips' brand of bro-comedy with social/political commentary.
Hell or High Water makes for a contemplative dramatic thriller that is fueled by great performances and strong direction.
Strong performances and beautiful cinematography elevate The Light Between Oceans, yet soap opera contrivances and uneven writing hold it back.
Lights Out makes for a lean and mean scare-delivering machine, but is less effective as a supernatural horror parable.
In the decaying America that Andrea Arnold bears witness to, there are two currencies: sex and violence, constantly intersecting as the crew makes their way across a divided country.
Ultimately, it may not be a fitting tribute vehicle to the late Robin Williams, but works as a fun watch if you're a huge Johnson or Hart fan.
Jiyen can be proud of helming a film with big notions.
Mayaanadhi starts off slow, explores an unusual romance between the duo, and then builds into a gripping thriller. The scriptwriters deserve due credit for how the movie's characters grow on you.
... Weiner is a documentary about why we believe and to whom, about what lies we are willing to let go, and about what we believe about ourselves. [Full review in Spanish]
Roger Stone is a very charismatic character... [Full review in Spanish]
P.K. is a landmark film that has come out at a relevant time in the current Indian and global political climate. Go see it and reflect on the difference between faith and religion.
ShahRukh is himself, the star. Deepika Padukone fits the role of Meena perfectly and looks beautiful as the Southern belle.
Witty, irreverent, sweet and real.
Ek Tha Tiger's lack of logic and script loopholes prove inconsequential to enjoying the film.
Shahrukh Khan has played this sort of role so many times and said the same lines over and over that there is nothing new to comment on.
For all the publicity in the universe, Heroine is a waste of time.

OMG walks a fine line between sermonizing and entertaining and has long patches of super-preachy kitsch. Yet the subject is so compelling that you come out with a smile on your face and perhaps a decision to open up your holy text.
Another blockbuster that one can sit through and smile at the cheesiness provided you've left your brains at home.

Shuddh Desi Romance is an important film because it is current and encapsulates a confused Indian youth who, without public discourse, in the face of moralistic right-wing groups and immense social pressure, seek their way out of limbo land.
Beautifully-shot frames and a half decent score do not equal a good film if it cannot engage the audience emotionally.
The diverse beauty of rural India is a character in this story. There are long moments of silence, uncomfortable, beautiful and empty, even if filled with song.
Dil Dhadakne Do is solid, old-fashioned commercial Hindi cinema with a universal story.
Prashant Nair, the director, has crafted a sweet, funny and very touching narrative that is universal.

Of course, Spectre is a victim of the current crop's very high standards -- compared to most cinema fare it is breathtaking, and any Bond fan will enjoy the meta romp through its own martini-stained history.
Mother's Day begs the question: Why do these movies keep happening?

There's a sense of familiarity with Finding Dory. It's not breaking new ground. But it also doesn't have to. Pixar has perfected the formula, and if it's not broken, there's no point in trying to fix it. It just works.
It's simply just a story about the bonds of friendship, doing the right thing when presented with a difficult decision and how we're ultimately shaped by our choices.
An adaptation worthy of Rowling's marvelous creation-a chapter that spins the story to ever more thrillingly dark, treacherous heights.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A story well-told and built upon the solid foundation of Blanchett's supremely capable performance.
Overreaches its niche as a glammed-up music video and can't survive with everything but the kitchen sink crammed in.
Wallows in self-referential smugness, deliriously amused with its own cleverness.

movie_review_blurb: Gia Coppola has taken the hazy danger of the well-heeled teen into another era of whatever-glam.

movie_title: La Camioneta: The Journey of One American School Bus (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Operatic and heartbreaking.

Delightful.
It's as if the director saw a Paul Greengrass fight and figured excitement is the result of confusion and loud noises.
Embracing ambiguity in a story of this magnitude is plain cowardly.

Gravity to spare and performances to talk about...worth a risk, even if you're prone to nightmares.

movie_review_blurb: Glee leaps past antiseptic politeness or political correctness-it's got its crosshairs on self-acceptance and personal pride, and the film proves the agenda is working.
Poised for the sort of surprised, congratulatory attention Cronenberg enjoyed for his relatively restrained The History of Violence, with the true-ish historical heft adding to the film's cache.

A staunch declaration of identification and reverence.
Martha Marcy May Marlene enters so richly into psychological horror it recalls those disturbing dramatizations of Jonestown that were big on TV in the '80s.
This four-hour opus about the fury of love and the love of fury is ritually fascinating, often excessive and, with a caution the film wields like a blade, achingly poignant.

The balance of naivete and insularly sweet exchanges are pleasing and comical but the film's painfully derivative.

The real mystery here is how this mess of a movie got such a stellar cast.

What audiences expect from this butterfly awakening song they'll get in spades.
OKA!, like the mysterious horn the characters hunt, is a real find.
Ccontrary to all of my bitter nudging, I found [it] both sweet and charming. It's just me: I hate precocious children.

To say the franchise is coasting along on fumes suggests it once ran on a full tank.

Equally nostalgic and fresh-faced, Guy and Madeline on a Park Bench is a bohemian musical that owes as much to Cassavetes Shadows as it does the French musicals of the '30s.
movie_title: Guy and Madeline on a Park Bench (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's a wonderfully moving meditation on the capacity of animals to inspire our imaginations and something applicable to educational markets as well as regular documentary audiences.

Formally, everything's in order-it's an attractive film with some ingenious action sequences-but the problems overwhelm the pleasures, leading to the conclusion that this film's trouble is under the hood.
Next to all this totally awesome glitz, it's "be happy with who you are" philosophy is as convincing as Selena Gomez's British English.
Director Seth Gordon gives us few thrills, little danger and no growth-potential.

Happy, Happy is the catharsis for anyone who's had a romance go south.
There's much to like in these chilly climes.
Moverman's camera keeps its hands off Harrelson's psyche, letting the drama result from a cool distance (when things get emotional in the third act, the film loses some potency).
You'll laugh and be offended, but if you watch it and don't want to be part of the solution, you'll know which side of the line you're on.

The playacting and oddly veiled contempt evoke Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf? (if rewritten as a comedy about immaturity and starring tweens) while the quick-and-sharp sibling dynamics are like the Duplass Brothers on lemon juice.

If this horror movie cashes in on the audience that echoes its character's awareness ("That's where the nucular thing happened, right?") then we're about to learn how low our national academic standards are.
The premise is fetching and feels like a mystery, particularly as the film orchestrates its story to make the work of the Alps group seem like a kind of heist.
What it provides (instead of the thematically clever dialogue of typically subtle French comedy) is biting wit, poignancy and, forsaking some structural nuisances, the summer's best bromance.
It's a great (if middle-of-the-road) family comedy to seek out.
The way Jacobsen tilts the scales between laughing at normality and laughing at perceived abnormality makes this a comedy feel like it's in a universal language.
This film provides a striking and immersive feeling of place and the ache of desire.
The soulless-ness of their empty plot of track homes and super-store existence invokes both Poltergeist and Employee of the Month.
As a summer movie for the kids: protect your progeny. Nightmares and bedwetting are bad. But teaching your kids to take death casually is just bad parenting.

A coming of age story in which the children better the world for the adults, Kore-Eda's heart is in the right place.
Doesn't mask its awe of the man, who comes off as a cross between a wise Buddha-figure and Santa Claus

It suffers from being too broad.
The mother/daughter drama should have played a bigger part in this film as the 87-minute runtime passes quickly and leaves us feeling utterly short-changed.
This is one of the super rare docs that packs an unbelievable punch despite its misguided aesthetics.
The film features some really intriguing conflicts and solid performances throughout.
You don't have to be a parent for it to wreck you and make you glad it exists.

Less a story loosely bound by cause and effect than a kind of scrapbook of memories, all of which convey the concerns of being super smart and mostly confused in a culturally mixed Manhattan, circa 1980.

movie_review_blurb: Your neighboring 8-year-old will giggle-and isn't that what it's all for?

Here, Leth makes Worthington's ledge a constantly frightening gimmick and the pacing between scenes is so effective, you'd be on the edge of your seat if the film didn't constantly make you feel for the back of your chair.
But just as the men in this film vacillate between horrible and endearing, you'll find yourself (whether male or female) being lost and won back by the film's charms, chiefly its cast.
Like the weaker cousin of Superbad.
It's not just the little film that could, it could be the last honest movie in Texas.
Jonah Hill is masterful at delivering an absurd story with so much sweetness, the nonsense ceases to get in the way.
He made a movie that wondrously stands on its marvelously amusing own but also pays pleasantly harmonious homage to the earlier versions which came before it.

I like filmmakers as fiercely independent as this one, directors who refuse to paint easy portraits for their audiences and make them use their brains to decipher the pluses and minuses of what is going on.
It's mesmerizing on multiple levels, and by the time it was over the fun I was having was so palpable I'm sure it was showing all over my body.
This is a grandly entertaining voyage, one full of mystery, intrigue, suspense and majesty the majority of the other films sadly lack.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: This jovially cantankerous and brutally funny comedic noir comes ever so close to returning the director to those mid-90's glory days.
The man behind The Iron Giant and The Incredibles, Bird has crafted another wondrously original and emotionally magnificent cinematic adventure the likes of which simply must be seen to be believed.
Kwapis' directorial license should be revoked, while his movie should be divorced from theaters as soon as possible.

This is as hard-hitting and infuriating a document as you're likely to see all year, the director dropping his usual in-your-face style and adopting an observational tone perfectly suited to the material.

The film can't decide if it is a satire, if it is a gross-out comedy or if it is just a tasteless romp full of the usual Sandler shtick. It's a frustrating mess, and just thinking about it is enough to make me furrow my brow in aggravated disgust.
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: That's more than enough for me, and I'll certainly live free in the knowledge this cinematic everyman still had one more ecstatically exhilarating adventure left in him. Yippee-ki-yay indeed.

More, the whole thing is layered in sentimentality, at times drowning in it, Koltai and company never able to find the right balance for the melodrama which could have made it a forcefully moving female-driven winner.
It is, without question, a masterful picture, a truly heartwarming winner that's about as pure and as fantastic as even the most timeless fairy tale.
The thing is, as much fun as much of it is if I'm going to go to the theater for bubblegum I'll take the visceral real-world thrills of Live Free or Die Hard over this any day.
The first two thirds are really something special.

Her Nora is a complicated mess you can't help but fall in love with even as she manages to tear herself apart, and watching Posey slowly bring this frazzled female to love's doorstep is absolutely joyous.

The thing is, while I am the first to stand up and shout about the dangers of the climate crisis, I also don't need to be hit over the head with what is going on in the world with a didactic sledgehammer.

so much built-in love and affection here these yellow creations could probably read the phone book and people would pay to see it, what I have to say on the matter not going to change one single thing even in the slightest bit.
So color me pleasantly surprised because Hicks' version (written by freshman scribe Carol Fuchs) is easily the director's best since his Oscar-winning 1996 opus Shine.
Duris, so good in The Beat that My Heart Skipped, is simply marvelous here. His Molière is a complex creature of intelligence, insecurity, sincerity, obstinacy and burgeoning brilliance.
While the solution to I Know Who Killed Me isn't worth talking about, if Lohan wants to know who it was who killed her career sadly all she's got to do is look in the mirror.
It does not stop, never slows down and refuses to let the audience catch their breath. It is, without question or hesitation, maybe the perfect Summer action movie of all time.
The movie moves well, doesn't overstay its welcome and has just enough absurd irreverence to maintain interest.
Becoming Jane is one of those perfectly charming and well put together motion pictures I desperately want to like more than I actually do.
In other words, I hated it, and if there are a better three words in the English language to adequately explain my feelings I must admit I have not yet been able to find them.
I must admit, I still have trouble recommending the film even with Anthony's magnificence.

Besides, if I start talking about the film I'll only get depressed, and when a woman of my three-decade age gets depressed all that therapeutic ice cream goes straight to her thighs and none of us want that, now do we?
Unfortunately this film, for all its mesmerizing merits, isn't that alarm, the clock still ticking to doomsday while we all continue to sit by and twiddle our thumbs in misbegotten stupor.
But for the time I was in the theater I did have a good time, and in the case of Black Sheep that's more than enough tasty mutton to warrant a mint sauce recommendation.
Not only does the film treat its characters with respect and without condescension, it does so even when their actions border on the indefensible.

More, while I certainly don't have a problem with the strong pro-environment message and the heartwarming morals at the center of the Baxter family's struggles, I can't help but think there are better ways to push them over on an audience than this.

Parts of this are just ludicrous. There are two full-blown musical numbers, a segment that looks like it was lifted from Dancing with Stars and a bizarrely idiotic sequence feeling like a surreal homage to, of all things, Saturday Night Fever.
The film forced me to wring my hands in frustration, moments of pure cinematic pleasure contrasted with sequences so unbearable I almost don't know what to say.
The film is a kaleidoscope of wonderment, much of it bouncing off of the screen in such robust and magnificently layered detail a person needs to see it twice just to take it all in.

A little frantic, not always sure of where it is headed, nonetheless the film is still a stupendously delicious good time full of laughter, tears, heartbreak and bittersweet chocolate covered strawberry love.
Matchett, Schiff and Naga all contribute solid support, while Krause is downright exceptional as the nondescript accountant suddenly falling into media-fueled paranoia.
Besides, rousing sports stories with even a smidgen of talent behind them always seem to choke me up (if only a little bit) and this one definitely does that and then some.
It is almost as if the film is standing right on an audience's throat, the unrelenting nature of this biological terror every bit as gripping and pulse-pounding as it was in the 2004 original.
This is a sexual drama not for the squeamish or for the easily offended, but for those looking for adult entertainment and not the usual summer CGI whiz-bang this one fits the bill and then some.
More, I can't shed my enthusiasm for what Kazi accomplished, the philanthropic legacy he has crafted to give voices to the voiceles a simply stunning achievement.

All excitement and anticipation aside, no two ways about it this sequel is also a frightful disappointment, the fairy tale clearly over no matter how much I and so many others would rather wish otherwise.
I adored it, fell madly in love with each frame each note each nuance each lyric.

Posey commands the screen, so heartbreakingly hysterical there should be an entirely new definition for what it is the actress is able to accomplish within this story's modest (if constantly evolving) storyline.
Thankfully, Linney and Byrne are so good, so absolutely mesmerizing, many of these flaws can be at least partially overlooked thanks to them.
By the end, I actually forgot who it was I was watching play the part, and if there is a truer testament to this woman's talent then that I admit to not having the first clue as to what it is.

But it all ends up being such deliciously scary stuff, and the comeuppance leveled upon the attackers is so gloriously macabre (and warranted), putting up with a few distasteful bits is a hardship I'm almost happy to endure.
While far from perfect, by and large I found myself mesmerized.
Still, I liked this movie. Schroeder is excellent, while veteran Mulroney is even better.

This thing moves in so many directions, and moves there so unbelievably quickly, by the time I thought I had it all pretty much figured out the director had the film suddenly sprinting off into an entirely new direction altogether.
But so what? This is one of the most entertaining films I've seen all year, Burt and Linda's story so shocking and unconventional I couldn't believe my eyes.
The real reason to see this, of course, is to watch the cast of amiable superstars play off one another for a third, and hopefully delicious, time. None of them disappoint.

The actors get some good mileage out of the material (especially Bridges, turning up The Dude mojo to maximum), and the water images certainly pack a punch, but I still couldn't shake the over-familiar vibes emanating from this thing's every move.

The payback element still applies to this sequel, but maybe I am just over this whole genre of "torture porn." Either that or I just can't handle the gender reversed plot structure. Simply put, I did not like this movie.
More than a biobic, far more than a musical, this spectacular film is a triumph on so many levels I almost don't even know where to begin.
Still, I'm willing to give the multitalented filmmaker a break and give his latest concoction an ever so slight recommendation.
Thankfully there is Roberts, and all by her lonesome she's almost enough to make me feel like I'm being a bit too hard on this movie.

But, like I said, I never hated sitting in the theater. Heck, moments (including the highly imaginative way the malevolent menace intent on destroying the Earth is visually depicted) here and there are actually pretty darn wonderful.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Then there is Horsley. Waititi's partner and the inspiration for the picture, she is a true marvel. I adored the actress in this, her Lilly a total original I couldn't wait to see more of.
His one real scene with Jackson is a mesmerizing corker, the two actors sparing with one another like two master chess players trying to find the most director route to their opponent's jugular.

The big problem here is director Gore Verbinski. It is almost as if his massive success on the first two has given him personal license to indulge in every single whim and idiosyncrasy the filmmaker could ever imagine.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: I got the odd feeling watching the last of the summer three-quels that Chan, Tucker and director Brett Ratner were making all of this up as they went along, Jeff Nathanson's script nothing more then a template to improvise crazily off of.

I just wish you'd get the chance to see it in a theater like I did, because if more people took the time to do so then maybe we might actually get more intelligently crafted relationship comedies like it.
Delpy's script is light and bouncy, her direction of the material allowing it to deftly move around corners and into emotional interiors with a buttery ease that's almost sublime.
While I wish Berg and Carnahan would have dove a bit deeper, for all they don't accomplish what they do deliver is still worthy of rousing applause.
This isn't an easy sit, and by the time it was over my heart was virtually shattered thanks to the human wreckage vividly on display.

It took me a little while, but as the film progressed (and even as every inch of me tried to fight against it) the women at its core wrapped me up inside their lives and actually made me care about the choices they were all going to make.
This isn't a good movie, and while there are one or two decently solid laughs none of them make up for the obnoxious venality of the rest of it.
It is, in almost every single way, an absolute mess, watching the darn thing (especially for fans of the books) and not coming away disappointed pretty much a complete and total impossibility.
movie_title: The Seeker: The Dark Is Rising (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The film is terrific, and for fans hungry for an intelligently constructed pot boiler reminiscent of The Parallax View and All the President's Men this one should ease their starvation perfectly.

Cruel and beautiful, emotional and infuriating, this adaptation of Eileen Chang's short story is as difficult as it is wondrous, all of it coming to an end in a head-scratching climax that's as fantastic as it is upsetting.
While there are some delightful moments overall this is pretty familiar stuff, none of it really going in a direction we haven't seen both before and better.
For me, this is sublime poetry. Pitt's performance grows in majesty as things progress, while Affleck is absolutely mesmerizing as the fame-hungry Ford.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Right after the screeching tires of a stunning rain-soaked car chase come to a crashing halt the picture starts moving in a direction growing more ludicrous and asinine by the minute.
To call this disappointing would be a massive understatement.

It helps immensely that Oliver's script is a minor revelation. The author refuses to take the easy way out but, just as importantly, she also refuses to treat her characters as anything other than real flesh and blood human beings.
In the end, this is a quest worth taking, and those with the passion to do so might just find a cinematic rapture boarding on the spiritual.
The film builds terror with ferocious subtlety, admittedly using some of the usual clichés to do so but still in a way that feels fresh and new (even if they're not).

This story turns in on itself to finally emerge an emotional powder keg, the final weight of everyone's choices causing a landslide of second guessing and emotional chaos impossible to walk away from.

The director never overdoes it, never pushes things into a maudlin state of saccharine melancholy, instead allowing for people and their actions to speak for themselves in a way that's doesn't preach or force a certain perspective.
movie_title: Things We Lost in the Fire (2007)

movie_review_blurb: While many of the individual pieces work brilliantly, the final tricky answers to the puzzle simply do not work; the twist at the end neither earned nor welcome leaving a bad taste in my mouth refusing to go away.
In the end, if the movie connects with you on an emotional level than it is easy to enjoy even with its ample shortcomings.
Still, this is still awful fascinating stuff at times, and little Marla Olmstead is easily one of the more singularly beguiling little kids I've seen grace the silver screen in ages.

The movie evokes the ghosts of Fritz Lang, Billy Wilder, Robert Siodmak and Don Siegel, the grit and grime so thick a person almost feels covered in its ghoulishly seductive sheen as they walk out of the movie theater.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The writing here is as honest as any I've experienced this year, the script a continuous symphony of all of life's numerous bells and whistles that continually keep us all coming back for more.

Its melding of Raymond Chandler gumshoe noir with Dick's trademark dour cybernetic musings is borderline magnificent, the themes of alienation and identity so inherent in the novel nearly popping right off the screen.
For the Bible Tells Me So is a great documentary and an even better motion picture, and as a testament to faith and family I can't imagine a finer example than this.
movie_title: For the Bible Tells Me So (2007)

movie_review_blurb: At a certain point you have to wonder how long audiences are going to keep flocking to this stuff.

Expertly acted by the two leads and wildly entertaining for a about half the picture this new version goes wildly off the rails, the final thirty minutes or so implausibly executed it's just about enough to make a viewer's head spin.
Make no mistake, there is a euphoria to Phoebe's journey, a delicious wonderment to her ability to see the world through a prism entirely her own.

I'd claim it was a blatant rip-off of Kinji Fukasaku's fantastic 2000 cult masterwork Battle Royale, but then I'd have to try and compare this insipidly inert monstrosity with that explosively sensationalistic classic.
